Freeman-Mills","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west-portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image1-8efuijxkqy.jpg?v1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-36-52-278_9e429b9ca04fd9bd.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image1-kxu5uo7fdc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn88@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-36-55-511_046d874f51e79e5e.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image2-wp3yejygzm.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn53@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-10-260_4dd0d42dfa4864a9.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image3-x0n1xvaeys.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn42@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-10-469_c657e365cde62c71.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image4-ilabwjuytn.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn97@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-00-867_0db7b4cf9b6de2fe.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image5-rkhl6gfrsa.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn32@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-57-964_f22b3ab69745850a.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image6-jucsbvf8q5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn38@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-09-660_10b8ecf6752b7265.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image7-hasuxsqtfb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn37@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-00-728_318d886802407fde.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image8-ayclex1ggj.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn72@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-36-57-680_a0a67e99aad40e97.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image9-gbjv2zdhnt.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn42@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-24-723_7a41f462716b2963.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image100-etz8xvuw7y.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn23@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-55-216_d3ee53da296b7c31.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image111-sfsdhqp7uj.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn31@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-16-399_5e596e88971069d8.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image122-eevvfnupyb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn9@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-37-11-962_f4736616f07d8ec1.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image133-labl10wpqj.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn91@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-17-777_e12ed4d7077e867a.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image144-uubln43mjg.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn82@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-09-153_83fdd87a51956763.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image155-0xa2epploi.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn67@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-37-25-752_e44f178b82f5af96.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image166-mtqsnxijqi.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn37@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-36-57-598_74900e695abcf39a.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image177-icyjphxard.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn97@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-12-185_b3ce10d56fc601fe.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image188-oan1ycesla.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-27-234_4582ba490e4b56a5.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152097-cameras-news-another-set-of-photos-from-the-american-west---portraits-of-a-simpler-time-image199-iaypnw6a7p.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn51@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-02-397_1ab448c9f4b4fe9d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209019},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"Olympus OM-D E-M1 Mark III review: Technological powerhouse","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/olympus/151867-olympus-omd-em1-mk-3-review-mark-iii","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"499\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-e-m1-mark-iii-image1-4t2mz8yxgu.jpg?v1\"> <p>Sensor size. Yes, it still matters. The Olympus OM-D E-M1 Mark III is part of the Micro Four Thirds format system, which uses a smaller sensor size than you'll find in many other competitor DSLR and mirrorless cameras. But this sensor format is both its Achilles' heel and its launchpad.&nbsp;</p><p>On the one hand, a larger sensor would mean greater light gathering capacity and resolution potential. But it also means added bulk - something this Olympus doesn't suffer. Its equivalent lenses are smaller too.</p><p>Furthermore, the E-M1 Mk3 brings a host of innovative tech, truly going to town with a bounty of shooting modes that make this camera a technological powerhouse that stands apart from its peers.&nbsp;</p><h2>An answer for everyday photography</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>Image Stabilisation up to 7.5EV</li> \n  <li>High-Res Shot up to 80MP</li> \n  <li>Live ND Shooting up to 5EV</li> \n  <li>Starry Sky AF&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Focusing Stacking in-camera</li> \n  <li>Pro-Capture High Time-lapse with 4K video output</li> \n  <li>Cine 4K video, plus Slow motion Full HD videos up to 120fps</li> \n  <li>Bluetooth, Wi-Fi and NFC connectivity&nbsp;</li> \n </ul><p>The E-M1 MkIII packs a remarkable feature list - and we've only included the highlights above. That's something Olympus continues to do: unearth new ideas that are genuinely useful.&nbsp;Scroll down page after page of the jungle of a menu system - in itself a problem that takes some navigational learning - and you'll find heaps of extra goodies.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-e-m1-mark-iii-image1-6ry8abjivj.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><p>But it's not just the shooting modes that are the reason to buy this camera. It also packs a super image stabilisation system, which is a key reason why the E-M1 Mark III is so easy to use. It's now rated up to 7.5EV (depending on which lens is being used), so it's completely possible to get sharp detail in handheld shots with an exposure a couple of seconds long. That's truly mind-boggling stuff. &nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>This system is used in other creative ways too. Take in-camera focus stacking. This bracketing mode can composite multiple images at different focus planes to create a final image with greater depth of field. All in-camera, shot handheld, with manual control over the depth range and number of shots. It's a macro photographer's dream, plus that Micro Four Thirds sensor already has greater depth of field than larger sensor rivals at equivalent aperture settings.</p><p>Or how about High-Res Shot. Effective for static scenes, this uses the stabilisation system to move the focus by a pixel at a time, to multiply the sensor and capture a super-high resolution image. You'll get a 50MP image (rather than the 20.4MP native resolution of that sensor). There's also a tripod mode that results in an 80MP image - but you'll need greater attention to technique with this mode, ensuring the camera (and subject) is very steady.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-964lgubjzq.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><p>Live ND Shooting is now part of the arsenal too. It creates the effect of a Neutral Density filter up to a strength of 5EV - useful for reducing the incoming light equivalent, enabling longer exposures that may be useful when capturing intentional movement. You may think that reducing light for a small sensor is a bad idea, but for making long(er) exposure shots in bright light it's useful.</p><p>Yet that's the beauty of the technology - in a number of scenarios the E-M1 Mark III does away with the need for extra kit like a tripod or remote release or ND filter. It's about making life easier for the image maker.&nbsp;</p><p>Elsewhere there's Starry Sky AF. If you are into astrophotography, this mode breathes new life into the Olympus system. It really does exactly what it says on the tin: you'll get sharp detail of the stars every time, with ease. No need for manual focus, or for any degree of uncertainty or guesswork.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-6bmfzluozj.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><p>Olympus continues to up the video game, too. We still have Cine 4K (24fps) and 4K (30fps) video recording, plus slow-motion HD video (up to 120fps).Crucially, there's a flat colour profile and an 'OMLog 400' profile now included, meaning you can get a wonderful colour rendition.</p><p>Pro-Capture mode is perfect if your reactions are not quite up to scratch&nbsp;for action. When the shutter is half-pressed, the camera now buffers up to 35 shots before the shutter is fully pressed for capture, enabling a delayed reaction of up to 3 seconds. &nbsp;</p><p>So, while the E-M1 Mark III has a smaller-scale sensor, there are so many occasions where shots are made possible by Olympus innovation.</p><h2>King of action?</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>Electronic viewfinder (EVF), 2.36m-dot resolution</li> \n  <li>Fully articulated 3-inch touchscreen</li> \n  <li>121-point phase-detection autofocus system</li> \n  <li>18fps silent shutter with continuous AF</li> \n  <li>Weather-sealed magnesium alloy body</li> \n  <li>400,000 shutter cycles</li> \n  <li>420-shot battery life</li> \n  <li>AF joystick control</li> \n  <li>Dual SD card slot</li> \n </ul><p>Last year Olympus launched a new flagship camera, the E-M1 X. The E-M1 inherits much of the best bits from this camera - but in a smaller form-factor that costs a lot less. Like the E-M1 X, its magnesium alloy body is weather-sealed to an IPX1 rating, making this one tough camera.</p><p>A battery life of 420-shots is par for the course. However, charging via USB is now possible, so you can keep the battery topped up on-the-go between shots by using a power bank. Also, with a vertical handgrip added that life can be doubled. The compatible batteries and handgrip are the same ones used in the E-M1 Mark II, which could make an upgrade kinder on the pocket.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-e-m1-mark-iii-image1-j9pnsjtmiy.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><p>It's the viewing experience where the E-M1 Mark III is let down a little. There has been no update of the 2.36-million dot EVF. With a 0.74x magnification, the view is not quite as crisp or immersive as larger examples like the E-M1 X and Panasonic Lumix G9. That said, it's still a good viewfinder with a solid 120fps refresh rate.</p><p>It's not just the screen's refresh rate that's fast - the E-M1 Mark III gets out of the blocks at great speed. Start it up and the shutter and finder are all ready to respond with no real lag.</p><p>Wade through the AF modes; Eye Detection, Face Detection, Tracking. It all seems to work rapidly and for the best part reliably. For example, Tracking AF sticks to a subject very quickly - and even right up to the near edges of the frame.&nbsp;</p><p>There is some groundwork to put in to ensure the best possible performance, though. For example, if you stick to the entire 121-AF-point array for a single subject, you'll experience focus dropping to the background. The single point or 9-AF point options are more consistently sharp in our experience.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-5zn1axh30s.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><p>We tracked a bike moving at reasonable speed towards and away from the camera. Continuous Tracking AF did lag a fraction, especially closer to the camera, so we're not top of the pile here. However, lateral movement is fine.&nbsp;</p><p>Olympus has implemented an AF joystick. This is a tool that most action photographers want in order to select AF points quickly. Here it feels lovely and operates smoothly, whether viewing on screen or through the viewfinder. A side benefit of the joystick is that the limited functions of the touchscreen are less relevant.&nbsp;</p><p>You also have some seriously impressive high-speed burst rates: 18fps silent shutter with continuous AF (silence is a dream for wildlife photography); and up to 60fps with the electronic shutter.&nbsp;For more intense action sequences, we feel the continuous 'low' burst rate of 9fps (mechanical shutter) is best, delivering consistently sharp AF and longer sequences.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-tyug7mojvr.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><p>Yes, high-speed sequences are handled quickly by the new TruePic IX processor and can be recorded onto a UHS-II SD card. The second SD slot is not UHS-II compatible, so you're relying on slot one for optimum performance.</p><p>Expect approximately 65 frames before the camera slows (when shooting Raw &amp; JPEG - or approximately double that in JPEG only). No sooner have you finished a new sequence and the camera is virtually ready to go again - surely a benefit of smaller file sizes compared to rival cameras?</p><h2>Micro Four Thirds sensor quality</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>20.4MP Micro Four Thirds sensor</li> \n  <li>ISO 200-25,600 (extd. ISO 64)</li> \n  <li>Image Stabilisation to 7.5EV</li> \n  <li>TruePic IX processor</li> \n </ul><p>The elephant in the room is sensor size. We're looking at the same 20.4MP Micro Four Thirds sensor as found in the E-M1 Mark II, with a sensitivity range of ISO 200 to ISO 25,600. Bottom line, there are other cameras for the same price packing larger sensors and more pixels.&nbsp;</p><p>Studio tests analysing resolution and image noise with its impact on detail will show that the E-M1 Mark III does not compete with those larger sensor cameras in like-for-like tests.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>Image noise is relatively absent in images up to ISO 800, though, and it's really only from ISO 3200 that we're starting to lose detail and contrast. Also, default noise reduction for JPEG images is heavy handed in our view.</p><p>However, images are not taken in a lab but in the real world - and that is where the Olympus technology (and vast choice of sharp, wide aperture lenses) comes into play.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-jdczdfrybb.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><p>Image stabilisation up to 7.5EV means a slower shutter speed can be used, where appropriate. Any increase in light intake, such as through increasing shutter speed (or a fast aperture lens), can make a big difference in image quality.&nbsp;</p><p>And what is the point of more pixels if the picture is not sharp in the first place? We feel that the E-M1 Mark III is very reliable across a wide range of scenarios to at least get focusing right and minimise motion blur.&nbsp;</p><p>With regards to how images look, Olympus has long given us a beautifully warm and natural colour rendition. The plentiful Art Filters are more suited to the entry-level cameras, but here the natural picture mode with auto white balance are a great combo. Like some other camera systems, in JPEG images there is a small loss of detail in bright magentas/reds.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-k190ble6ga.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><p>We should also note that the evaluative metering system is one of the most reliable out there. You also get manual control at your fingertips through exposure compensation, plus a handy range of spot metering modes.&nbsp;</p> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 28 Jun 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":7639,"bgimg":"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-e-m1-mark-iii-image1-4t2mz8yxgu.jpg?v1","linkMd5":"5f421b66382a451fe88c22b2bdba37f8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn12@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-51-462_e9a2de7f49179401.webp","destWidth":748,"destHeight":499,"sourceBytes":100133,"destBytes":62116,"author":"Timothy Coleman","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-e-m1-mark-iii-image1-4t2mz8yxgu.jpg?v1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn12@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-51-462_e9a2de7f49179401.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-e-m1-mark-iii-image1-6ry8abjivj.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn91@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-00-381_a030f468c47a0dfe.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-964lgubjzq.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn32@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-20-735_b436236d6d769be0.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-6bmfzluozj.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn8@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-18-271_834b1b298d7b3070.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-e-m1-mark-iii-image1-j9pnsjtmiy.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn3@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-20-214_6cb3416f86af0bfb.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-5zn1axh30s.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn71@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-36-55-055_0d5fe6f4a2f43feb.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-tyug7mojvr.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn94@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-37-25-128_5a2e658f8f4a713e.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-jdczdfrybb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn88@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-36-53-901_8f4dc78df5457bc5.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151867-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-iii-image-samples-image1-k190ble6ga.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn10@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-01-150_53df23e091194fd8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209017},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"Simply spectacular photos: The very best of the Sony World Photography Awards 2020","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/sony/152500-sony-world-photography-awards-gallery","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"371\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image3-ywe4idk8vv.png?v1\"> <p>The Sony World Photography Awards are a highlight of the photography scene every year, inviting photographers of all types to submit their best images in a variety of categories and genres to be judged against each other.</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/drones/news/133911-best-drone-photos-ever-stunning-images-taken-from-up-high\" rel=\"follow\">Best drone photos ever: Stunning images taken from the sky</a></li> \n </ul><p>Countless photos are submitted, and the final shortlists and winners are almost always jaw-dropping, whether for their beauty or harshness, or any number of other reasons. This year's main awards have just been announced, and we've gathered together some of our favourite images from the lists for you to browse right here. Prepare to be amazed.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-oa7sitf5jh.png\" /></p><h2>Seeds of resistance</h2><p>The overall winner of Sony's competition this year is&nbsp;Pablo Albarenga, a photographer whose series documents the threat posed against environmentalists in Brazil who are trying to protect habitats and areas from deforestation and damage.</p><p>They're pictured literally laying down their lives, contrasted with the area they protect in a stitched-together amalgam.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image2-jz9crlynxx.png\" /></p><h2>Testament</h2><p>This is another from&nbsp;Albarenga's series, and showcases another of his chosen details - the landscape on the right has the first signs of deforestation at play in it, shining a spotlight on exactly how the environments these citizens care about could be threatened so gravely.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/sony/151522-jaw-dropping-photos-sony-world-photography-awards\" rel=\"follow\">These stunning award-winning pro photos will blow you away</a></li> \n </ul><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image4-3fioy2aukq.png\" /></p><h2>Bleak</h2><p>The winner of the Architecture section,&nbsp;Sandra Herber, has created an amazing series of images by simply and sparsely photographing fishing huts on Lake Winnipeg, in the cold of winter. The freezing conditions positively chill you as you look but the individual character of each hut is also manifest.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image5-iamgflzw0n.png\" /></p><h2>Vibrant</h2><p>We love the painted fish on this hut from&nbsp;Sandra Herber's series - it's a splash of vibrant colour in a landscape that's largely monochromatic, and sets off the isolation of the hut really nicely.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image6-6px2l1ughj.png\" /></p><h2>Looming</h2><p>Jonathan Walland's photos of buildings look like something created in a laboratory - he cleverly dials back all colour and focuses only on the building in focus to create a sort of silhouette of their shape and lines, which strips them down to their architectural essentials.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/gadgets/news/148387-the-best-tanks-and-armoured-fighting-vehicles-of-all-time\" rel=\"follow\">Some of the best tanks and armoured vehicles of all time</a></li> \n </ul><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image7-jjtuflvroc.png\" /></p><h2>Contrast</h2><p>This, another from&nbsp;Jonathan Walland's series, shows that even when a building is constructed with a more modern aesthetic, and curved lines, Walland can still distil it into an essential form, something that looks like the very first sketch its designer might have come up with.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image8-ecidz7cnym.png\" /></p><h2>Big brother</h2><p>José De Rocco's series came third in the Architecture bracket, and features stark images of buildings framed in such a way that their surface details become the story of the image itself.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/gadgets/news/146570-17-uses-of-technology-that-make-us-cringe\" rel=\"follow\">17 awful uses of tech that'll make you cringe</a></li> \n </ul><p>Take the side of this supermarket - its red tiling dominating the frame but that security camera also drawing the eye inescapably.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image9-lvkphcbsrj.png\" /></p><h2>Grunge</h2><p>Dione Roach took second place in the Creative category for this series, boldy titled&nbsp;Kill Me With an Overdose of Tenderness, which collages together snapshots from the online world in a punk-rock aesthetic that applies a grungey layer to our sometimes clinical social media channels.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image100-di4qthaypy.png\" /></p><h2>Objets d'art</h2><p>The items photographed by&nbsp;Luke Watson in this series are all recovered from conflicts, some as old as the First World War, and repurposed into rudimentary pinhole cameras.</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/141060-fantastic-photographic-firsts\" rel=\"follow\">29 fantastic photographic firsts</a></li> \n </ul><p>It's a repurposing that prompts you to think about the object's original intended use, and the creative potential that countless everyday items therefore implicitly carry with them.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image111-haxkzyju1t.png\" /></p><h2>Patched up</h2><p>This helmet from&nbsp;Luke Watson's series is another starkly clean image demonstrating how something can be given a new lease of life. The tech world is particularly shabby when it comes to re-use, so this is a challenging photographic idea.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image122-fnsyiwqedj.png\" /></p><h2>The medium is the message</h2><p>The bleached-out landscapes from&nbsp;Hashem Shakeri's series&nbsp;Cast Out of Heaven showcase a large-scale housing project near Tehran, but do so with the harsh sunlight and blanched building making for a stunning, heavenly sort of environment.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/141224-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken\" rel=\"follow\">The most famous ghost photographs ever taken</a></li> \n </ul><p>This image of a blank advertising hoarding has something distinctly dystopian about it, too.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image133-eua5kfq8cs.png\" /></p><h2>Picture-book</h2><p>This image is another example of how interesting&nbsp;Shakeri's photos are - the focus is shared by multiple levels of depth in the image, with the huge blocks in the foreground just as detailed as those behind, all of them huge to the point where it's actually quite hard to grasp a real sense of scale.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-di7v8ukb2g.png\" /></p><h2>Disinfect</h2><p>Hugh Kinsella Cunningham's photos showcase the experience on the ground dealing with Ebola in the DRC - carefully stained in a dark-room while being developed, adding to the palpable sense of threat you get from looking at images of so deadly and transferrable a virus.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-0dxatymuof.png\" /></p><h2>Playing their part</h2><p>The Hong Kong protests have inspired many over the last year or so, and have also started to offer blueprints for other protestors around the world.&nbsp;Chung Ming Ko's images of protestors are dramatically lit and carefully framed to humanise them.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/apps/news/152226-politicians-re-imagined-in-famous-portrait-paintings\" rel=\"follow\">Modern politicians fantastically re-imagined in famous portrait paintings</a></li> \n </ul><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-viwtc2zqg3.png\" /></p><h2>Intimacy</h2><p>The phenomenon of lifelike dolls being used by people as emotional aids has been around for a while, and unfairly lambasted without sufficient empathy, and&nbsp;Didier Bizet's photos go to great lengths to remind people that these dolls are not toys or oddities, but almost always more complex figures.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-ab5z3sdpg8.png\" /></p><h2>The reality behind the label</h2><p>Youqiong Zhang explores the ethics and realities of mass-production in Africa in their series, which showcases just what a factory looks like and is actually like to work in, without dehumanising or overlooking the experiences of its workers.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/gadgets/news/148708-the-best-battleships-and-warships-of-all-time\" rel=\"follow\">The best battleships and warships of all time</a></li> \n </ul><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-jgnf3scpu6.png\" /></p><h2>Her environment</h2><p>Robin Hinsch showcases some of the devastating impact of industrial exploitation and fossil fuel extraction in the Niger Valley. It contrasts the brutality of the environment that oil extraction leaves behind with the citizens being forced to live in the shadow of fossil fuels.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-j4rmkwjbxe.png\" /></p><h2>Hand-crafted</h2><p>This image might be hard to decode initially, but once you realise that it's a series of pelts stiched together into one piece, things become clearer.&nbsp;Álvaro Laiz's series shines a light on the life of the&nbsp;Chukchi on the Bering coasts.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-uazlqtslu9.png\" /></p><h2>Modern forest</h2><p>It's sometimes hard to remind yourself that so much agriculture in the modern world isn't out in the open but in enormous warehouses like this one, carefully monitored to ensure even growth - it's like a bizarre, managed version of a forest, as captured by&nbsp;Luca Locatelli.</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/152215-photos-from-old-west-american\" rel=\"follow\">A lawless time of discovery: Early photos from the Old West</a></li> \n </ul><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-kyetjnsmwh.png\" /></p><h2>Who needs the sun?</h2><p>Another of&nbsp;Luca Locatelli's images, this showcases how smaller plants are grown in banked shelves of lit-up beds - it's taking farming to the next level, and again is a photo that obviously forces us to reconsider how we think about the source of even our plant-based food.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-sackn1xrq9.png\" /></p><h2>World in miniature</h2><p>We can't get our heads around this photo - nothing we do stops it looking like a miniature set from Wes Anderson's Isle of Dogs.&nbsp;Ronny Behnert's images are framed with a great distance and white out the oceans around the Torii pictured to create surreal, serene landscapes.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/instagram/148290-fantastic-street-artist-transforms-the-world-with-pixel-art\" rel=\"follow\">Fantastic street artist transforms the world with incredible pixel art</a></li> \n </ul><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-8ejcvxugio.png\" /></p><h2>Off-putting</h2><p>There's a lot of interesting facets to the photos submitted by&nbsp;Florian Ruiz, not least the fact that they are subtly stitched together from various images, giving them that slightly off, wobbly look. The industrial landscape pictured is near&nbsp;Xinjiang in China, a dried-up salt lake where the dust blows around like the Old West.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-wca6pbmxbk.png\" /></p><h2>A memorial</h2><p>The final image we've selected comes from&nbsp;Chang Kyun Kim, who has taken a haunting look at some of the remaining sites of Japanese concentration camps in the US from the Second World War, where buildings are still standing testament to the imprisoning of so many innocents. As&nbsp;Chang Kyun Kim observes, most were in locations so harsh and unwelcoming that nothing has been built there to replace them.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/151936-photos-american-west\" rel=\"follow\">These old photos from the American West will make you yearn for a better time</a></li> \n </ul> 0x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-0dxatymuof.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn1@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-37-12-696_1ba1ff2793704033.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-viwtc2zqg3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn36@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-15-660_24c767822942216b.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-ab5z3sdpg8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn36@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-06-864_d8e892ae79097216.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-jgnf3scpu6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn67@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-27-309_3b6e0e90f72e7c18.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-j4rmkwjbxe.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn2@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-23-772_6e25d40439f6162a.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-uazlqtslu9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-19-829_731d45ebc8504de4.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-kyetjnsmwh.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn70@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-11-932_b994b04e919fc562.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-sackn1xrq9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn59@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-55-067_bf718c8be936ec6f.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-8ejcvxugio.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn34@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-01-737_fb051e6386220c7a.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/152500-cameras-news-the-sony-world-photography-awards-2020-have-been-awarded-to-some-spectacular-images-image1-wca6pbmxbk.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn40@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-26-652_d3f3c10a34bc819d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209022},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"Best mirrorless cameras 2020: The best interchangeable lens cameras available to buy today","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/124653-best-mirrorless-cameras-budget-to-high-end-mirrorless-lens-cameras-to-buy","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"493\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/124653-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-mirrorless-cameras-2020-the-best-interchangeable-lens-cameras-available-to-buy-today-image1-f806ranv4z.jpg?v1\"> <p>You're looking to buy a mirrorless camera - sometimes called a compact system camera (CSC) - but don't know what to go for? That's not necessarily a surprise, as mirrorless cameras are more diverse and popular than ever before, with more brands, lens mounts and systems mixing up the offerings.</p><p>In this best-of feature, we round up the best mirrorless system cameras of to suit all tastes and abilities. Whether that's based on a budget for a first-time buy, or a larger chunk of cash for a pro-spec full-frame mirrorless model, <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/122777-best-dslr-cameras-full-frame-and-interchangeable-lens-cameras-to-buy\" rel=\"\">here's the best DSLR alternatives</a> to consider.</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/deals/146122-best-camera-deals\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"follow noopener\"><strong>Best cheap camera deals 2019</strong></a></li> \n </ul><h2>A quick lesson in lenses</h2><p><strong>Lens mount</strong></p><p>First thing's first: cameras don't work in a one-size-fits-all kind of way. Brands like to keep their own heritage and, as such, manufacturers tend to have individual lens mounts. The exceptions are: Micro Four Thirds, supported by Panasonic Lumix G, both Olympus Pen and Olympus OM-D models; and the Leica L mount, which will offer S lenses from Panasonic and lenses from Sigma.</p><p>Elsewhere there are a whole host of considerations, each tied to their respective manufacturers: it's EOS EF-R for Canon's full-frame models and EOS EF-M for its APS-C models; it's E-mount for Sony Alpha (formerly NEX) and A-mount for its full-frame (SLT) cameras; and XF-mount for Fujifilm.</p><p>Others are already past their sell-by date: Pentax gave up on the Q-mount for Pentax Q in 2017; NX-mount for Samsung NX (and specifically the smaller NX-M mount for the NX Mini) are both now defunct; and the 1-mount for the Nikon 1-series was also binned in 2017.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Focal length equivalent</strong></p><p>Each lens will have a \"mm\" marking on it, such as 12-24mm, to convey the angle of view it will deliver. The lower the number the wider the angle of view, so more will \"fit in\" to a given scene.</p><p>It's a bit more complex than that, however, as different camera systems have different sensor sizes that give different focal length equivalents, but stick to that rough rule above and you'll have an approximate understanding on what you're getting.</p><h2>Best budget buy</h2><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/139813-cameras-review-panasonic-lumix-gx800-review-image1-czv1pgh9o0.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><h3>Panasonic Lumix GX800</h3><p>squirrel_widget_139813</p><p>What the Panasonic Lumix GX800 really gets right is its price proposition. There's a lot of features on offer for its sub-£300 price point, which will see camera keenos flocking to check out this accomplished little mirrorless system.</p><p>Downsides are the lack of any viewfinder option (but then just look at the G80/G85 instead, below), some plasticky build elements, limited battery life, that 12-32mm collapsible lens not being the best, and the odd choice of a microSD card (most cameras use full-size SD, but not here).</p><p>All things considered, however, those above nit-picks are far from major problems. Especially when decent image quality, an autofocus system that'll better almost anything else at this price, a raft of compatible Micro Four Thirds lens options, 4K capture and accessible touchscreen controls use are all par for the course.</p><p><strong>Read our full review: </strong><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/panasonic/139813-panasonic-lumix-gx800-review-an-affable-affordable-entry-level-mirrorless-camera\" rel=\"\">Panasonic Lumix GX800</a></p><h2>Best affordable all-rounder</h2><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/138328-cameras-review-panasonic-lumix-g80-review-image1-zjvHIdy3eM.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><h3>Panasonic Lumix G80</h3><p>squirrel_widget_138328</p><p>Panasonic has boat loads of great G-series cameras. The one that offers the most bang for your buck is the G80. It's like a mini DSLR in many senses, combining a built-in viewfinder with a vari-angle touchscreen LCD to the rear.&nbsp;</p><p>With a lot of the technology taken from the top-end G-series line, the G80 walks the line between pro and budget. There's 4K video capture, decent image quality and all the control that you could possibly want. One of our favourite features is Pinpoint autofocus.&nbsp;</p><p>If you're looking for a one-stop-shop then few can offer as much as the G80 for the price. If you do have a bit of extra cash and prefer a more compact-style camera <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/sony/139263-sony-a6500-review-a-mini-mirrorless-powerhouse\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">then the Sony A6500 is also one credible camera</a>.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Read our full review:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/panasonic/138328-panasonic-lumix-g80-review-affordable-foray-into-4k\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Panasonic Lumix G80 review</a></p><p>&nbsp;<img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/140065-cameras-review-fujifilm-x-t20-review-image1-purd3uqmv0.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><h3>Fujifilm X-T20</h3><p>squirrel_widget_140065</p><p>Retro done right, that was our sentiment about the X-T20, the cut-price little brother to the X-T3 (further below). Its combination of retro design, quality construction, top notch image quality and decent general performance make it a great all-rounder.</p><p>The X-T20's biggest issue is nothing to do with its own performance: it's the presence of the Panasonic Lumix G80 (above), depending on which one you can find for less cash (it's increasingly close).</p><p>But while the Panasonic is like the brains of the mirrorless camera world - it's hugely capable, with 4K modes, Pinpoint autofocus and weather-sealing - the Fuji X-T20 is the heartfelt, retro-styled champ. And sometimes it's better to listen to your heart than your head, right?</p><p><strong>Read our full review: </strong><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/fujifilm/140065-fujifilm-x-t20-review-the-retro-touch\" rel=\"\">Fujifilm XT-20 review</a></p><h2>Best small all-rounder</h2><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/139263-cameras-review-sony-a6500-review-image1-proxewb3pl.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><h3>Sony A6500</h3><p>squirrel_widget_139263</p><p>Smaller than the Panasonic offering, yet still with a built-in viewfinder, the A6500 is a highly accomplished little camera.</p><p>Indeed, you'll struggle to find a mirrorless cameras with quicker autofocus. The A6500 is up there with the best-in-class in this regard, while its processor is hugely capable of backing up its 11fps burst mode figures. Image quality is great, too, while its 4K video capture will appeal to a whole other audience.</p><p>The biggest drawback of the Sony system is its over four-figure asking price. It's really pricey, which is why the Panasonic G80 (above) may appeal more, but for the right user the Sony is certainly worth it. Oh, but its battery life isn't great , so you'll want to carry a spare.</p><p><strong>Read our full review:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/sony/139263-sony-a6500-review-a-mini-mirrorless-powerhouse\" rel=\"\">Sony A6500 review</a></p><h2>Best DSLR-alternative / prosumer mirrorless</h2><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142737-cameras-review-panasonic-lumix-g9-lead-image-image1-e8dgkj4gsh.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><h3>Panasonic Lumix G9</h3><p>squirrel_widget_142737</p><p>If you're looking for a DSLR alternative with some added mirrorless benefits then the G9 ticks all the boxes. It's a very impressive bit of kit indeed.</p><p>The G9 offers oodles of appeal by cutting out the typical irks that many mirrorless cameras can present: it's got a huge viewfinder with near-instant startup; a super-fast 20 frames per second (fps) continuous autofocus mode at full resolution; it adds a light-up status LCD screen (which you'll find nowhere else except on a mirrorless Leica); and offers improved battery longevity with up to 920 shots per charge.</p><p>Having used the Lumix G9 with a variety of lenses for two weeks - in both South Africa on safari and Vietnam while travelling - we've come to think that it's perhaps the finest mirrorless cameras that money can buy. Indeed, it's so good that we'd lean away from the Fujifilm X-T2 (see below) in its favour.</p><p><strong>Read our full review:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/panasonic/142737-panasonic-lumix-g9-review-the-finest-mirrorless-camera-that-money-can-buy\" rel=\"\">Panasonic Lumix G9 review</a>&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/145646-cameras-review-hands-on-fujifilm-x-t3-review-image1-bktd4euk5c.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1067\" /></p><h3>Fujifilm X-T3</h3><p>squirrel_widget_145646</p><p>If there's been one inherent weakness for many mirrorless cameras it's their ability to cope with moving subjects. Fuji has tackled this head-on with the X-T3, which is among the best mirrorless cameras for capturing moving subjects.</p><p>Beyond just being good at shooting fast action, the X-T3 is an exceptional all-round camera too. It's well built, looks great, the image quality is that high-quality Fuji standard, and there's all the control and decent lens back-up that you could want. <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/fujifilm/143639-fuji-xh1-review-camera-mirrorless-x-h1\" rel=\"\">We think it even trumps the X-H1</a> in many regards (and the Panasonic G9, above, is better than that Fuji offering anyway).</p><p><strong>Read our full preview: </strong><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/fujifilm/145646-fuji-xt3-review-fujifilm-verdict-specs\" rel=\"\">Fuji X-T3 initial review</a>&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141141-cameras-review-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-ii-product-shots-image1-rexkqn7c69.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><h3>Olympus OM-D E-M1 Mk II</h3><p>squirrel_widget_141141</p><p>If it's speed you want, it's speed you'll get, with this Olympus capable of capturing up to 18 frames per second.</p><p>Also principal to its success is the built-in image stabilisation - which is perhaps the best sensor-based system we've ever used - and its super-quick reactions across the board, from start-up, to autofocus, burst speed, capture and playback.</p><p>Ultimately, the Olympus OM-D E-M1 Mark II is among the best Micro Four Thirds cameras for advanced photographers shooting moving subjects. That said, the Panasonic Lumix G9 (above) offers an even more compelling 20fps burst alongside a better viewfinder, which will ultimately be more favourable (and it's cheaper than the Olympus to boot!)</p><p><strong>Read our full review:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/olympus/141141-olympus-om-d-e-m1-mark-ii-review-the-most-formidable-olympus-camera-ever\" rel=\"\">Olympus OM-D E-M1 Mark II review</a></p><h2>Best street shooter</h2><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/124653-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-mirrorless-cameras-2017-the-best-interchangeable-lens-cameras-available-to-buy-today-image8-udfksretno.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><h3>Fujifilm X-Pro2</h3><p>squirrel_widget_136158</p><p>The X-Pro2 is a camera for the modern professional. Or the nostalgic shooter, given its rangefinder-like stylings.</p><p>Sure, it's a quirky camera, but that's what we love about the X-Pro. It stands out from the crowd with its complex \"advanced hybrid multi viewfinder\" (that's what Fujifilm likes to call it): think rangefinder-like use thanks to a corner-positioned digital rangefinder overlay screen (<a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/fujifilm/131959-fujifilm-x100t-review-naughty-but-niche\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">as found in the X100T</a>) which can show a 2.5x or 6.0x magnification of the active focus point for precision manual focus, ensuring correct focus for close-up shooting.</p><p>We'd still like to see a vari-angle touchscreen rather than fixed panel only, but given that the X-Pro2 seems to be looking inwards to its existing pro user base rather than outwards to newcomers, we suspect the target audience will remain happy without.</p><p><strong>Read our full review: </strong><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/fujifilm/136158-fujifilm-x-pro2-review-pro-perfection\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Fujifilm X-Pro2 review</a>&nbsp;</p><h2>Best mirrorless camera for video</h2><p>Video or movie capture has been going from strength to strength in mirrorless cameras, with many now very capable. Our current favourite is the Panasonic, but die-hard videographers may call on Sony's A7S II as the very best model going (something only the Panasonic GH5S can really throw into contention).</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/139811-cameras-review-panasonic-lumix-gh5-review-image1-2dbmywt6kq.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1067\" /></p><h3>Panasonic Lumix GH5</h3><p>squirrel_widget_139811</p><p>The camera world has been moving at a fairly slow pace over the last few of years, with only small gains to be made. If you were to compare the GH5's image quality to the earlier GH4, for example, then the gains aren't that significant.</p><p>But when it comes to video the GH5 offers out-of-this-world top quality. There's 4K capture with 10-bit 4:2:2 output (at 30fps; 60fps is 8-bit 4:2:0) and a host of pro spec features that put it head and shoulders above anything else you can buy at this price point (well, except the company's own GH5S, below)</p><p>Sure, it might be pipped in stills quality by the Fujifilm X-T3 (above), but for video features the Lumix GH5 is still a great choice.</p><p><strong>Read our full review:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/panasonic/139811-panasonic-lumix-gh5-review-hail-the-4k-king\" rel=\"\">Panasonic Lumix GH5 review</a>&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/143125-cameras-review-hands-on-panasonic-lumix-gh5s-image1-tv1zfoeiw6.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><h3>Panasonic Lumix GH5S</h3><p>squirrel_widget_143125</p><p>Here's where things get super specialist. But if you know your stuff then the GH5S will get your salivating at its video prowess.</p><p>The GH5S has a lower-resolution sensor than the GH5 (above), as it's designed with video in mind. That sensor offers dual native ISO, which can deliver a far cleaner image at higher ISO settings - which is great for nighttime and low-light work.</p><p>There's also no image stabilisation system within the camera, which pros with rigs will prefer to avoid any \"jumping\" that can happen when such a system is present.</p><p>It's hard to call the Lumix GH5S a consumer product, but for higher-end users this will be the small-scale, affordable and capable 4K product they've been waiting for.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Read our full preview:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/panasonic/143125-panasonic-lumix-gh5s-initial-review-the-4k-cinema-pro\" rel=\"\">Panasonic Lumix GH5S initial review</a></p><h2>Best full-frame / professional mirrorless camera</h2><h2><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/143157-cameras-review-hands-on-sony-a9-review-image1-aupryiuwk4.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></h2><h3>Sony Alpha A9</h3><p>squirrel_widget_143157</p><p>The Sony A9 is a mirrorless camera like no other, although it's not a true \"mirrorless\", as its SLT (single lens translucent) definiton attests.</p><p>But let's not get stuck down too much regarding the camera's technological make-up, because when it comes to ticking all the pro-level boxes, the A9 has so much right.</p><p>In full flow, it offers 20 frames per second (fps) with no live view black-out, phase-detection AF that covers virtually the whole frame, and a generally reliable Lock-On tracking AF.&nbsp;To back-up this&nbsp;class-leading performance, Sony also has one of the best lens line-ups for sports and wildlife photography.&nbsp;</p><p>In terms of image quality the A9 delivers exactly what we would expect: it's a camera that's able to make great images in both bright and low-light conditions, particularly excelling when the conditions are tough.</p><p>It's so good, it asks questions of the DSLR elite (the <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/nikon/136437-nikon-d5-review-olympic-effort-from-pro-dslr\" rel=\"\">Nikon D5</a> and <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/canon/136560-canon-eos-1d-x-mark-ii-review-the-fast-and-the-furious-part-ii\" rel=\"\">Canon EOS 1D X II</a> are no longer as safe as they once were) and still leaves a big question hanging on the <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/nikon/145453-nikon-z7-review-specs-price\" rel=\"\">forthcoming Nikon</a>, <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/canon/145625-canon-eos-r-review-mirrorless-full-frame-specs\" rel=\"\">Canon</a> and <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/panasonic/145820-panasonic-lumix-s1-s1r-full-frame-specs-design-pro-details\" rel=\"\">Panasonic full-frame mirrorless</a> systems.</p><p><strong>Read our preview: </strong><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/sony/143157-sony-a9-initial-review-phenomenal-speed-from-the-full-frame-mirrorless-master\" rel=\"\">Sony A9 initial review</a></p> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 12 May 2020 13:46:00
