mirrorless-cameras-2017-the-best-interchangeable-lens-cameras-available-to-buy-today-image8-udfksretno.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn96@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-26-126_7fc63e5c20271aee.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/139811-cameras-review-panasonic-lumix-gh5-review-image1-2dbmywt6kq.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn100@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-54-148_0fbdf403d0e928a9.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/143125-cameras-review-hands-on-panasonic-lumix-gh5s-image1-tv1zfoeiw6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn51@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-36-53-937_0266ec8c25dc7799.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/143157-cameras-review-hands-on-sony-a9-review-image1-aupryiuwk4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn46@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-10-390_87a8f74a8652f5c7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209019},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"Best 360 cameras 2020: The best VR and 360 cameras, no matter your budget","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/137301-best-360-cameras-the-best-vr-and-360-video-cameras-no-matter-your-budget","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"498\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/137301-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-360-camera-lead-image7-m10giyzos4.jpg?v1\"> <p>With <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/ar-vr/buyers-guides/132945-best-vr-headsets-high-end-and-cheap-vr-headsets-to-buy\" rel=\"follow\">virtual reality headsets</a> becoming more popular and platforms like Facebook and YouTube supporting 360-degree photos and videos, it's no surprise to see more 360 cameras coming to market.&nbsp;</p><p>There is now a range of capable cameras available at wildly different budgets. Each has their own appeal, so the choice really comes down to budget and what you want the camera for. Something small you can slip in your pocket and take on a jaunt or an action camera that can survive being dropped, bashed and used underwater?&nbsp;</p><p>Take a look at our list of the&nbsp;best VR and 360 cameras available to buy, whatever your budget.&nbsp;</p><h2>Best 360 camera for video capture</h2><p><img src=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/137301-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-360-camera-lead-image5-gfbvb7rtk4.jpg\" width=\"748\" height=\"499\" /></p><h3>GoPro Max</h3><p>squirrel_widget_168074</p>\n <ul>\n  <li>6K spherical video capture capabilities</li>\n  <li>Voice control and live-streaming</li>\n  <li>OverCapture user-friendly video editing system</li>\n  <li>1,600mAh battery</li>\n  <li>Hypersmooth video stabilisation</li>\n </ul><p>When it comes to video, especially action-cam footage, GoPro has always managed to produce incredible results. The GoPro Max is another camera from GoPro making waves.&nbsp;</p><h4>Video capture capabilities</h4><p>This device possibly offers the best 360 video capture capabilities of any device we've seen. Likely because it's capable of capturing&nbsp;6K video at 30fps. Where the GoPro Max really shines though is in usability. <a href=\"https://gopro.com/help/articles/block/gopro-app-overcapture\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"follow noopener\">GoPro's&nbsp;OverCapture</a> video editing system allows users to easily create brilliant footage from their recordings.&nbsp;</p><p>This&nbsp;OverCapture tech even offers the ability to flatten 360 videos to make them viewable on any device - including TVs and create a \"tiny planet\"-like view&nbsp;or make sharp transitions at certain points.&nbsp;</p><p>The results are something pretty special and set this 360 camera apart from the crowd.&nbsp;</p><h4>Durability and flexibility&nbsp;</h4><p>Like other cameras in the GoPro range, the&nbsp;GoPro Max is a flexible and durable camera. This device is waterproof up to 16 feet and can be used underwater and with some abuse - making it suitable for use with watersports.</p><p>A removable&nbsp;1,600mAh battery and a USB-C port that supports fast charging make it pretty flexible too. A touchscreen even lets you see what you're capturing and widens its appeal.&nbsp;</p><p>360 video makes a lot of sense in extreme sports areas and with the sort of footage GoPro fans will be capturing. It's therefore easy to see why&nbsp;GoPro created the Max (itself a soft reboot of the older Fusion camera) and where it sits in this market. As such, it's well worth considering.</p><p>The&nbsp;GoPro Max offers some of the best results we've seen in terms of capture quality. It's also easy to use with the OverCapture functionality on a smartphone. It boasts a great feature list and impressive specifications, but it does come with a pretty hefty price tag.&nbsp;</p><h3>Conclusion</h3><p>GoPro's expertise when it comes to action cameras has come to bear brilliantly on the Max — it's great for filming whatever activities you'd want it to, and is also adaptable. When you need 360 footage, it'll produce the goods, but can also film all sorts of other quality video.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Pros:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>User-friendly video editing system</li>\n  <li>Tripod mounting as standard</li>\n  <li>Waterproof and durable build</li>\n  <li>Excellent footage results</li>\n  <li>Touchscreen so that you can see what you're capturing</li>\n </ul><p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>One of the more expensive 360 camera options</li>\n </ul><h2>Most feature-rich 360 camera</h2><p><img src=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/137301-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-360-camera-lead-image6-xh61cbffpi.jpg\" alt=\"\" /></p><h3>Insta360 One R</h3><p>squirrel_widget_182791</p>\n <ul>\n  <li>5.7K 360 capture or 4K wide-angle</li>\n  <li>H.265 encoding with \"advanced image processing\"</li>\n  <li>FlowState Stablisation\" - offers \"gimal-like\" stablisation</li>\n </ul><p>The Insta360 One R is one of those devices that tries to offer you the world on a stick. It's a feature-packed camera that comes in various editions with bundles that include different lenses or attachments and extras. There's even an aerial edition that'll fit certain Mavic drones.</p><p>It comes with an \"invisible\" selfie stick and a multitude of capture options that make things interesting. Everything from night shot capabilities to HDR mode, bullet time, starlapse, timelapse and more. It has a compact frame that can be made waterproof with the accompanying housing.</p><h4>Capture quality</h4>\n <ul>\n  <li>360-degree field of view</li>\n  <li>Upto 5760 x 2880 at 30FPS</li>\n  <li>HDR and standard video modes, timelapse, timeshift, bullet time and more</li>\n  <li>100Mbps video bit rate</li>\n </ul><p>The Insta360 One R offers some impressive capture quality. Considering all the recording options you get, it seems to do a lot of things and does them well.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>It also has swappable lenses and different mounting options meaning you can use it to capture all sorts of footage, whatever you're planning on recording. Whether action shots using a helmet mount or chilled out strolls through the country with a selfie stick.&nbsp;</p><p>We enjoy interesting modes like \"bullet time\" where you swing the camera around your head like you're wielding a mace, capturing a surrounding view of yourself and the environment. Other capture options include everything from HDR footage to timelapses.</p><h4>Video and image sharing</h4><p>You can edit it all within the app or the <a href=\"https://www.insta360.com/download/insta360-oner\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Insta 360 Studio</a> and there's <a href=\"https://onlinemanual.insta360.com/oner/en-us/editing/postedit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a detailed guide explaining how</a> to do that. From there you can then easily share it on your favourite social media platform without much fuss.&nbsp;</p><p>In the free video editor, you can add keyframes and move between various views including tiny planet, fish eye, standard view and more. The software isn't as powerful as something like DaVinci Resolve, but it's good enough to allow for editing, speed ramping, tweaking and even cutting out background noise from your audio.&nbsp;</p><h4>Conclusion</h4><p>The Insta360 One R manages to pull off being a jack of all trades without much in the way of compromise. A brilliant little camera with a lot to offer and plenty of highlights too.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Pros:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>A multitude of capture modes and footage options</li>\n  <li>Easy to use free editing software</li>\n  <li>Swappable lenses and mounting options</li>\n </ul><p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>Some elements of the software and UI can be a faff</li>\n </ul><h2>Most affordable 360 cam</h2><p><img src=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/144544-cameras-buyer-s-guide-samsung-gear-360-image4-mdenb1ktpg.jpg\" /></p><h3>Samsung Gear 360 (2017)</h3><p>squirrel_widget_136768</p>\n <ul>\n  <li>IP53 (Dust and Splash-proof)</li>\n  <li>Various capture modes including video, photo, time-lapse, looping video and landscape HDR</li>\n  <li>1,160 mAh battery</li>\n  <li>Wi-Fi 802.11 a/b/g/n/ac (2.4/5GHz), Wi-Fi Direct, Bluetooth v4.1, USB 2.0 (Type-C)</li>\n </ul><p>The Samsung Gear 360 is part of the company's \"Gear\" range of smart products designed to accompany the various <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/phones/buyers-guides/samsung/145854-best-samsung-phones\" rel=\"follow noopener\">Samsung flagship phones</a> available. As such, this 360 camera works well with both the Samsung Gear VR (to view the photos) and the latest Samsung phones via <a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.samsung.android.gear360manager&amp;hl=en_GB\" rel=\"follow\">the accompanying app</a>.&nbsp;</p><p>Despite this, the camera is actually pretty capable, easy-to-use and boasts a number of specifications that make it interesting. It's also one of the most affordable 360 cameras available.&nbsp;</p><h4>Capture quality</h4>\n <ul>\n  <li>360-degree field of view</li>\n  <li>4K video capture (up to&nbsp;4096 x 2048 at 24FPS), 15MP photos (5472 x 2736)</li>\n  <li>Micro SD card slot compatible with&nbsp;upto 256GB&nbsp;</li>\n </ul><p>The Samsung Gear 360 uses two 360-degree lenses to capture either 4K video or 15MP images through a variety of capture modes including video, photo, time-lapse, looping video and landscape HDR. The results are fairly good, especially for the price of this camera.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>However, like many of the other 360 cameras out there, the fully stitched images are quite clear close-up, but distant objects are fairly blurry. The stitching itself though&nbsp;is well done and the split between the two images is often barely visible.&nbsp;</p><p>This camera pairs with <a href=\"http://www.samsung.com/global/galaxy/gear-360/#compatibility\" rel=\"follow noopener\">a range of Samsung phones</a> and will also work with <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/phones/reviews/apple\" rel=\"follow noopener\">Apple iPhones</a>, but frustratingly won't work with other Android devices. If you have a compatible smartphone you can access a live view of the camera for capturing purposes, as well as access to a wide range of different settings and tweaks.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>You don't need a phone to capture images or video if you don't want to though. A small monochrome screen on the device allows you to easily power on the camera and switch between the basic capture modes as well as settings to snap photos on the go.&nbsp;</p><p>We also like the addition of the tripod mount underneath which allows you to put the camera to more adventurous uses if you should feel the need.&nbsp;</p><p>The Samsung Gear 360 is&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/phones/news/138727-ip-ratings-what-do-they-actually-mean\" rel=\"follow noopener\">IP53-rated</a>, making it dust and splash proof, but not fully waterproof like the GoPro Max. It is compact and ergonomically well designed though, making it easy to take with you. It's small enough to fit nicely in your pocket and pop it out when you need it.&nbsp;</p><h4>Video and image&nbsp;sharing</h4>\n <ul>\n  <li>130-minute battery life when recording&nbsp;2560 x 1280 at 30fps</li>\n  <li>Sharing via connected Samsung phone</li>\n </ul><p>The Samsung Gear&nbsp;360 captures images and video that can be shared via the app on your smartphone. It can also be accessed, processed, edited and shared on PC or Mac with the accompanying <a href=\"http://www.samsung.com/uk/support/model/SM-R210NZWABTU%20\" rel=\"follow noopener\">Action Director software</a>.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>Thanks to a USB-C connection, it's not only easy to quickly charge this camera, but also to easily download the images captured on the MicroSD card. The software can then be used to stitch the captured images into a 360-viewable photo or video and shared from there.&nbsp;</p><p>If you're using the Smartphone app, you can share directly from there. You can also start a live broadcast via Facebook or YouTube too, though obviously the latter requires passing the data from the camera to the phone and then onwards, which results in lower-quality resolutions.&nbsp;</p><p>The Samsung Gear&nbsp;360 is an easy-to-use camera. Although the photo and video results aren't necessarily the best, the price point of this device and flexibility of its features and settings make it pretty appealing.</p><h3>Conclusion</h3><p>The stitching of images and videos is also surprisingly impressive and a much speedier process than the Acer Holo 360 - especially when using the Action Director software on PC.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Pros:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>Quick image and video processing via <a href=\"http://www.samsung.com/uk/support/model/SM-R210NZWABTU%20\" rel=\"follow\">Action Director software</a></li>\n  <li>USB Type-C charging/interface port</li>\n  <li>Great ergonomics and compact design</li>\n  <li>Includes tripod mount</li>\n </ul><p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>Only compatible with Samsung phones and Apple iPhones&nbsp;</li>\n </ul><h2>Most premium 360 camera</h2><p><img src=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/144544-cameras-buyer-s-guide-garmin-virb-360-image9-vj3uohi68g.jpg\" /></p><h3>Garmin VIRB 360</h3><p>squirrel_widget_174818</p>\n <ul>\n  <li>Tripod mounts and grips included</li>\n  <li>Four microphones for spatial audio recording</li>\n  <li>Single and dual lens capture</li>\n  <li>Various photo modes including&nbsp;single shot, burst, timelapse, 360-degree front and back</li>\n  <li>Wi-Fi, Bluetooth and NFC connections</li>\n  <li>Waterproof to 10 metres</li>\n  <li>Built-in sensors for G-Metrix data overlays</li>\n </ul><p>The Garmin VIRB 360 is simultaneously both one of the most expensive and most interesting 360 cameras on our list.</p><p>This camera is an impressive little box of tricks. Packed into the fat little body is some high-end tech. This includes not only two 360-degree lenses capable of capturing 5.7K footage and 15MP photos but also a mass of other tech too. There's&nbsp;GPS, GLONASS, barometer and accelerometer sensors designed to capture data as you record and four&nbsp;microphones for spatial audio recording too.&nbsp;</p><p>This gives you the power to create some pretty impressive footage using this camera, not just in quality, but also in the information you include. Videos look pretty awesome with speedometers and other&nbsp;G-Metrix data overlays visible during playback. Especially if you're planning on doing something sporty with the camera.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>The&nbsp;Garmin VIRB 360 is also designed to be rough and rugged. This 360 camera is waterproof to 10 metres, though Garmin doesn't reveal what, if any, IP-rating the body supports. Still, it shows it's capable of recording in wet environments and will stand up to some abuse.&nbsp;</p><p>In the box, Garmin has included two attachments which allow you to connect a tripod using the usual screw mount. A small and capable, hand-held tripod is also included which allows for some nifty and steady shooting if you can find somewhere to stand it.&nbsp;</p><p>This camera also includes another attachment which allows you to connect the camera to GoPro style mounts - opening up a world of possibilities for attaching to helmets, suction cups, handlebars and much more besides.&nbsp;</p><p>Capturing is as simple as pressing a button on top to take photographs and pushing a slide on the side to record video. An LCD screen on top gives you easy access to change basic settings and flip between capture modes too. The result is an easy-to-use camera that's a joy to play with.&nbsp;</p><p>Voice control is also an option saying \"OK, Garmin\" allows you to give verbal commands. You can then ask the camera to start/stop recording, take photos and more besides.&nbsp;</p><h3>Capture quality</h3>\n <ul>\n  <li>5.7K/30FPS, unstitched or 4K/30FPS, stitched</li>\n  <li>15 MP photo capture</li>\n  <li>Automatically stitched photos and videos</li>\n </ul><p>We were suitably impressed with the capture quality of the Garmin VIRB 360. It's not surprising that with such impressive specs under the hood, this camera is capable of not only capturing high-quality video but images too.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>As well as recording 360-degree video at a maximum of 5.7K, the Garmin VIRB 360 also has a number of other capture options that include standard stills from either lens, burst mode, timelapse capture and slow-motion too.&nbsp;</p><p>It's easy to grab imagery and video footage with just a couple of clicks and the camera automatically does all the legwork in processing what you've snapped too.&nbsp;</p><p>We did experience some minor issues with stitching occasionally with photos (people missing parts of their heads) but this is fairly common on these sorts of cameras and is often forgivable. Otherwise, the quality of the footage and imagery is pretty reasonable.&nbsp;</p><p>None of these cameras is yet mind-blowing in terms of the end results. Despite the specifications, the technology is not quite there yet and you can easily see the degradation in quality the further into the distance you look, but this camera still has a lot going for it.&nbsp;</p><p>The Garmin VIRB includes spherical stabilisation capabilities and footage can be edited to reduce shake and wobble with a simple couple of clicks. The results are remarkable too. It's the ease-of-use, brilliant capture capabilities and flexibility where this 360 camera really shines.&nbsp;</p><p>As if that wasn't enough, the camera is also capable of recording for up to an hour on a single charge. <a href=\"https://buy.garmin.com/en-GB/GB/p/562010#accessories\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Spare batteries and dual chargers</a> are available to purchase to keep on recording if you so wish too.&nbsp;</p><h3>Video and image&nbsp;sharing</h3>\n <ul>\n  <li>Spherical stabilisation capabilities</li>\n  <li>Free desktop editing software</li>\n  <li>Mobile app for settings tweaks and sharing on the go</li>\n </ul><p>For us, one of the highlights of the&nbsp;Garmin VIRB 360 is almost certainly the way it handles stitching of images and videos. This processing is done automatically on the device meaning it's almost seamless.</p><p></p><p>You can choose to use the <a href=\"https://buy.garmin.com/en-GB/GB/p/153276\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"follow noopener\">iOS or Android app</a> to share content while you're out and about or use <a href=\"https://buy.garmin.com/en-GB/GB/p/573412\" rel=\"follow\">the free desktop software</a> to edit footage once you're back home. But even importing photos and videos from the device onto your PC or Mac you'll find their already stitched and ready for viewing or sharing to Facebook, YouTube or wherever else you wish to use them.&nbsp;</p><p>There's a Google Cardboard functionality built right into the app too, meaning you can pop your phone into a VR headset and view footage you've captured in full 360-degree glory.&nbsp;</p><p>There's a lot of flexibility here. Apple users can even live stream via the smartphone app, so there are plenty of different ways to capture and share content.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>The Garmin VIRB 360 is one of the best 360-degree cameras we've seen. It's flexible, capable and powerful. We loved the automatic stitching and the easy-to-use accompanying app and software that make it a breeze to easily create and share your content.&nbsp;</p><h3>Conclusion</h3><p>Stand-out features include powerful video stabilisation, brilliant G-Metrix data overlays, easy editing and spatial audio recording.&nbsp;</p><p>For us though, the best feature is likely the one you'll take for granted - the automatic stitching and processing. This is seamless and results in content that can be viewed and shared as soon as it's exported.&nbsp;This means it can be seen without any dull waiting around for the camera to process the footage beforehand like we experienced with other cameras we've tested.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Pros:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>Automatic on-camera stitching and footage processing</li>\n  <li>Easy-to-use interface</li>\n  <li>Simple pairing and controls via Wi-Fi, Bluetooth and NFC</li>\n  <li>Free app and desktop software makes editing and sharing a breeze</li>\n  <li>Waterproofing and rugged design</li>\n  <li>Flexible mounts and adapters mean you can potentially stick it to anything</li>\n </ul><p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>&nbsp;Hefty price tag</li>\n </ul><h2>Most durable 360 camera</h2><p><img src=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/144544-cameras-buyer-s-guide-nikon-keymission-360-image10-cr7i8voay1.jpg\" /></p><p>&nbsp;squirrel_widget_174817</p><h3>Nikon&nbsp;KeyMission 360</h3>\n <ul>\n  <li>1,050mAh Lithium-Ion battery</li>\n  <li>Approximately two hours of charging time</li>\n  <li>198-gram bodyweight</li>\n  <li>Bluetooth 4.1/IEEE 802.11b/g Wi-Fi</li>\n  <li>microSD/microSDHC/microSDXC memory card compatible</li>\n  <li>NIKKOR 1.6 mm f/2.0 lenses</li>\n </ul><p>If an action camera and a 360 camera got together and had a baby, this would be the result. The&nbsp;Nikon&nbsp;KeyMission 360 features a rugged, durable and robust body housing some capable&nbsp;NIKKOR 1.6 mm f/2.0 lenses and the ability to capture UHD 4K footage or 23.9MP 360-degree stills.</p><p>If you're into extreme sports or want a 360 camera that's capable of functioning underwater, in snowy/freezing conditions or just stand up to rough handling then this might well be it.&nbsp;</p><p>The&nbsp;Nikon&nbsp;KeyMission 360 is&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/phones/news/138727-ip-ratings-what-do-they-actually-mean\" rel=\"follow\">IP6X and IPX8 rated</a> meaning this camera is capable of withstanding a multitude of environments and rough handling. It's&nbsp;dustproof,&nbsp;shockproof, weatherproof and waterproof too.</p><p>The camera's durable body allows it to be dropped up to two metres, used underwater up to 30 metres for 60 minutes and resist temperatures&nbsp;ranging from -10°C to 40°C. All these specs certainly make it an ideal candidate for extreme sports use or a great alternative if you're a bit of a clumsy buffoon.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>There are <a href=\"https://www.europe-nikon.com/en_GB/products/action_cameras/keymission_360_missions.page#accessories\" rel=\"\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">multiple accessories available</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> including everything from suction cups to chest mounts, selfies sticks, grips and more. Meaning you can use this 360 camera for pretty much anything you can imagine. It also supports a standard tripod mount, making it flexible and easy to use with a variety of mounts and attachments.&nbsp;</span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This camera also comes with a build-it-yourself cardboard headset you can use with your smartphone to view the images and videos in VR - for a more immersive view of the footage you've captured too. </span></p><h3>Capture quality</h3>\n <ul>\n  <li>Standard, timelapse, looping and superlapse video capture</li>\n  <li>7744 x 3872 still images (approx 23.9MP)</li>\n  <li>MP4 (Video: H.264/MPEG-4 AVC, Audio: AAC stereo)</li>\n  <li>2160/24p, 1920/24p, 960/30p, 640/120p, 320/240p video capture</li>\n </ul><p>The&nbsp;Nikon&nbsp;KeyMission 360 captures images up to a resolution of&nbsp;7744 x 3872 (approx 23.9MP) and video at a maximum of&nbsp;2160p at 24 frames per second. The results are fairly impressive and comparable with the other high-end cameras on this list.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>This 360 camera offers a number of capture modes including standard, timelapse, looping and Superlapse video capture. It also supports a self-timer which allows you to set up the camera ready for photographs or video and capture footage just the way you want.&nbsp;</p><p>Built-in Vibration Reduction technology uses information about the camera's position in the world to counter camera shake and stabilise imagery. This, in theory, should result in smooth video performance and clearer photos. Our experience during testing shows video performance that isn't quite as stable as we've seen with the Garmin VIRB, but this camera is a lot more affordable.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>Like the Garmin VIRB, this camera has separate buttons for video and photo capture, making it easy to ensure you're pressing the right button for the results you're after. The video button doubles as the power button, which can make things a bit fiddly at times but otherwise it's fairly user-friendly.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><h3>Video and image&nbsp;sharing</h3>\n <ul>\n  <li>Automatic in-camera stitching</li>\n  <li>Self-timer capable</li>\n  <li>Auto-download options</li>\n </ul><p>A highlight to the design of the&nbsp;Nikon&nbsp;KeyMission 360 is the power under the hood. This camera supports automatic in-camera stitching that processes photographs and videos seamlessly.</p><p>You can then use the accompanying app to download captured footage directly to your smartphone or plug it into a computer to access it from there.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>The Nikon&nbsp;KeyMission 360 is compatible with the&nbsp;<span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">SnapBridge 360/170 app for </span><a href=\"https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/snapbridge-360-170/id1162513075?mt=8\" rel=\"\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">iPhone</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and </span><a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.nikon.snapbridge.sb360170\" rel=\"\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Android devices</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. This app allows you to connect to the camera to access and tweak settings, download images and work the camera as a remote control.&nbsp;We found the app could be a bit flakey and not as user-friendly as others we've tried, but automatic pairing via Wi-Fi and Bluetooth is a breeze. There are some occasional connection issues, but nothing that prevents you from using the camera manually.&nbsp;</span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">We had some issues with video capture during our testing. Some experimenting combined with a thorough reading of the manual revealed that you need a microSDXC memory card with an SD Speed Class rating of 6 or faster in order to properly capture video footage. Lesser rated cards lead to recordings stopping unexpectedly.&nbsp;</span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The app allows you to manually or automatically download images and videos from the camera to your phone. They can then be shared from your phone straight to social media. This sharing is fairly easy, but sometimes held back by the problems with app connectivity.&nbsp;</span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Downloading to your computer and sharing from there is also easy and the fact the stitching is automatic really makes life a lot simpler. There's also a desktop utility for basic editing and tweaks available to <a href=\"http://downloadcenter.nikonimglib.com/en/download/sw/79.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"follow noopener\">download for free</a>.&nbsp;</span></p><p>The Nikon&nbsp;KeyMission 360 is an interesting option for those looking for a durable and rugged 360-degree camera. It's built to withstand all sorts of punishment and weather situations making it perfect for extreme sports in all manner of conditions. We found the video capture to not be quite as good as other 360 cameras we've tested. Video stabilisation isn't as good as the Garmin VIRB, for example, but the price of this camera makes it far more accessible.&nbsp;</p><h3>Conclusion</h3><p>This camera is also flexible and able to work with a wide variety of accessories and mounts. Meaning you can put it to use in whatever activity you're planning on. It takes pretty impressive 360-degree imagery and is a really capable device for the money.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Pros:</strong>&nbsp;</p>\n <ul>\n  <li>Automatic in-camera stitching of photos and video</li>\n  <li>Ability to download images directly to your phone</li>\n  <li>Durable design that's&nbsp;dustproof,&nbsp;shockproof, weatherproof and waterproof too</li>\n  <li>Affordable price point compared to other 360 cameras on this list</li>\n </ul><p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>\n <ul>\n  <li>No live streaming capabilities</li>\n  <li>Smartphone app connection is flaky and unreliable</li>\n  <li>In-app settings are somewhat limited</li>\n </ul><p>&nbsp;</p> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 17 Jul 2020 11:52:00 +0000","feedId":7639,"bgimg":"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/137301-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-360-camera-lead-image7-m10giyzos4.jpg?v1","linkMd5":"f16d60031787d51e4a54f35efc1d255e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-50-723_095fb861204cac8b.webp","destWidth":748,"destHeight":498,"sourceBytes":55663,"destBytes":34236,"author":"Adrian Willings","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/137301-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-360-camera-lead-image7-m10giyzos4.jpg?v1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-50-723_095fb861204cac8b.webp","https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/137301-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-360-camera-lead-image5-gfbvb7rtk4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/137301-cameras-news-buyer-s-guide-best-360-camera-lead-image6-xh61cbffpi.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/144544-cameras-buyer-s-guide-samsung-gear-360-image4-mdenb1ktpg.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/144544-cameras-buyer-s-guide-garmin-virb-360-image9-vj3uohi68g.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg","https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/assets/images/144544-cameras-buyer-s-guide-nikon-keymission-360-image10-cr7i8voay1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn0@2020_1/404.jpg"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209018},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"Canon EOS R5 vs EOS R6: What's the difference?","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/canon/152866-xx-embargo-xx","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"498\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/152866-cameras-news-vs-canon-image2-1wcbgd8ml7.jpg?v1\"> <p>Canon had been teasing that its EOS R5 mirrorless camera was coming - it <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/canon/151073-canon-eos-r5-8k-ibis-release\" rel=\"\">was first made public in February 2020</a> - but it arrives alongside an EOS R6 too. That's a bit of a surprise! Two cameras, but two very different prospects, so what's the difference between the EOS R5 and R6?</p><h2>Best for</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>EOS R5: Magnesium alloy body, 135.8 x 97.5 x 88mm, 738g</li> \n  <li>EOS R6: Polycarbonate body, 138.4 x 97.5 x 88.4mm, 680g</li> \n  <li>Both cameras: Full-frame sensor with EOS RF mount</li> \n  <li>Both cameras: Built-in image stabilisation (IBIS)</li> \n </ul><p>The EOS R5 as the ultra-high resolution solution with 8K video capability. Think of it as the mirrorless version of the <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/canon/135439-canon-eos-5ds-review-resolution-revelation\" rel=\"\">EOS 5DS DSLR</a>, ideal for landscapes and highly detailed work.</p><p>The EOS R6 doesn't deliver the same resolution or video potential as the R5 - but it's a very fast camera, with action and low-light in mind. Think of this more as the mirrorless version of the <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/canon/131682-canon-eos-7d-mark-ii-review-king-of-quality\" rel=\"\">EOS 7D II</a> (albeit with a larger sensor).</p><p>Both cameras feature Canon's built-in image stabilisation system, which is a first for the brand. By using a combination of sensors in the cameras' bodies in combination with lens-based stabilisation (where applicable) the Japanese company is claiming up to 8-stops of stabilisation can be delivered. That's a huge helping hand.</p><p>While both cameras are also weather-sealed, the R5 is a magnesium alloy build, so it's heavier, as the EOS R6 uses a polycarbonate body instead.</p><h2>Resolution</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>EOS R5: 45-megapixel full-frame CMOS sensor<br> \n    <ul> \n     <li>ISO 100-51,200 (102,400 expanded)</li> \n    </ul> </br></li> \n  <li>EOS R6: 20.1-megapixel full-frame CMOS sensor \n   <ul> \n    <li>ISO 100-102,400 (204,800 expanded)</li> \n   </ul> </li> \n </ul><p>Here's the biggest difference on paper. The EOS R5 has a 45 million pixel full-frame sensor. Canon says, thanks to it being part of the new system, it's capable of resolving more detail than any Canon camera before it - and that includes higher-resolution DSLRs too - because of the optical potential of the RF lens mount.</p><p>The EOS R6 has a 20.1 million pixel full-frame sensor, so less than half the resolution. That's still heaps of pixels though, more than many will need for most types of work. And having lower resolution can be a benefit when churning through dozens of files at a time.</p><h2>Performance</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>EOS R5: -6EV low-light autofocus / EOS R6: -6.5EV</li> \n  <li>Both cameras: <br> \n    <ul> \n     <li>12fps mechanical shutter (20fps electronic)</li> \n     <li>Dual Pixel CMOS AF II autofocus</li> \n     <li>Digic X processor</li> \n    </ul> </br></li> \n </ul><p>In terms of performance both cameras offer a lot that's the same. Their sensors are the same physical size. The stabilisation system equally effective.</p><p>Both also represent the first appearance of Canon's second-generation Dual Pixel CMOS AF system. If you've used a Canon before you might have heard about this: it first appeared on the 70D DSLR, showing off what was possible on screen-based autofocus. In its 2020 guise, however, it's quicker than ever before - as fast as 0.05s, Canon asserts - and also features eye/face/body tracking and animal detection.</p><p>Not that the EOS R5 and R6 are just for shooting your pets. Both cameras offer deep learning, so the more you shoot subjects, the more context the camera will have to understand your methods. Sure, dogs and cats are the dominant species it's programmed to recognise, but also birds - including birds in flight - will be a huge deal for a large swathe of enthusiasts.</p><p>The latest Digic X processor also means considerable speed: both can clack away at 12fps (mechanical shutter) at full resolution. So, yes, the EOS R5 can capture 540 million pixels of data in a second in that regard (it's actually more as a 20fps electronic shutter also runs at full resolution, meaning 900MP can be buffered within a second).</p><p>The EOS R6, on account of its larger 'pixels' on that sensor, is also more astute to low-light conditions. It can autofocus as low as -6.5EV, which is beyond moonlight conditions - more like candlelight really. The R5 isn't far behind, though, at -6EV, making it half a stop less capable there.</p><h2>Screen &amp; Viewfinder</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>EOS R5: \n   <ul> \n    <li>LCD: 3.2-inch, 2.1m-dot, vari-angle mount</li> \n    <li>EVF: 0.5in, 5.76m-dot 120fps refresh rate</li> \n   </ul> </li> \n  <li>EOS R6: \n   <ul> \n    <li>LCD: 3-inch, 1.62m-dot, vari-angle mount</li> \n    <li>EVF: 0.5in, 3.69m-dot, 120fps refresh</li> \n   </ul> </li> \n </ul><p>In sync with its ultra-high resolution, the EOS R5 also offers the higher resolution viewfinder, offering a massive 5.76 million dots. That makes it 1.92m pixels (1600 x 1200; as each dot describes one of the red, green and blue channels used to create one white pixel). Still, there's nothing more resolute out there in the consumer market.</p><p>By comparison the EOS R6 has a lower resolution offering, but it's still massively resolute at 3.69m-dots (1.23m pixels). Both offer 120 frames per second refresh rate too, for the most accurate to-eye view, so you don't miss a moment.</p><p>Both cameras feature vari-angle LCD screens for creative composition. The R5's is a little larger and more packed with pixels.</p><h2>Video Credentials</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>EOS R5: Maximum capture - 8K at 30/25/24fps</li> \n  <li>EOS R6: Maximum capture - 4K at 60/50/30/25/24fps</li> \n  <li>EOS R5: Dual cards (1x CF Express, 1x SD (UHS-II))</li> \n  <li>EOS R6: Dual cards (2x SD (UHS-II))</li> \n </ul><p>The headline feature of the EOS R5 is its ability to capture 8K video (DCI 17:9, UHD 16:9 using H.265 compression and 4:2:2 10-bit onto card). This is with a slight crop - Canon tells us the camera captures at 35MP per frame - at up to 30 frames per second.</p><p>The EOS R6 maxes out at 4K60p, but that's still impressive. The EOS R5 also offers this - but with 4K120 as an option to make quarter-time slow-mo editing a breeze.</p><p>Both cameras also offer Full HD at 120fps, Canon Log for grading, and clean HDMI out to 4K60 maximum (potentially due to the HDMI standard).</p><h2>Conclusion</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>EOS R5: £4,199.99, sales from 30 July 2020</li> \n  <li>EOS R6: £2,499.99, sales from 27 August 2020</li> \n </ul><p>So there you have it, two big deal pro-spec cameras with a different target user in each case.</p><p>Want the ultra-high resolution and/or 8K capture? The R5 will set you back £4,200 in the UK, arriving late July. Add an RF lens and you'll need deep pockets.</p><p>The R6 is £2,500 and will arrive later in the year, from late August. Hardly small change, but this looks like an all-round EOS R that, with the right lens attached, will become Canon's 2020 focus.</p> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 09 Jul 2020 12:01:00 +0000","feedId":7639,"bgimg":"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/152866-cameras-news-vs-canon-image2-1wcbgd8ml7.jpg?v1","linkMd5":"cb930e76c1363d99c942221d7109960f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn52@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-51-665_247fea6859ae19e9.webp","destWidth":748,"destHeight":498,"sourceBytes":68257,"destBytes":45214,"author":"Mike Lowe","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/152866-cameras-news-vs-canon-image2-1wcbgd8ml7.jpg?v1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn52@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-51-665_247fea6859ae19e9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209016},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"The most famous ghost photographs ever taken","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/141224-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"580\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image1-ksgkjn7rfa.jpg?v1\"> <p>Ghosts, the paranormal and the supernatural have always been debated. Do they exist?</p><p>Many people have reported sightings before, but without any real proof, they're usually disregarded as merely stories. Being able to take photos of spirits obviously helps the cause, but are all of them real or have some been doctored?</p><p>Here is a round-up of the most famous \"ghost\" photos of all-time. Some have been faked no doubt, but they look so good on first inspection they could definitely convert some non-believers.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image2-kq6fowhz8n.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"589\" /></strong></p><h2>William Mumbler - 1860s</h2><p>William Mumbler is credited with creating the first photo to show a ghost in the 1860s. But it wasn't a ghost at all, it was simply an accidental case of double exposing a negative while taking photograph of himself. The entrepreneur in him turned this into a business, where members of the public would have their portrait exposed with an image of a dead relative.&nbsp;</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image3-a1ozzfjca8.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"487\" /></strong></p><h2>Lord Combermere - 1891</h2><p>This image taken of the library at Combermere Abbey in Cheshire, England by Sybell Corbett clearly shows a figure sitting in the chair on the left. It's believed to be the ghost of Lord Combermere, a British cavalry commander in the 1800s.&nbsp;</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image4-nvr7q2bxhl.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"421\" /></strong></p><h2>Goddard's Squadron&nbsp;- Freddy Jackson - 1919</h2><p>This image was taken by Sir Victor Goddard, of his squadron in 1919. The ghostly image behind the fourth sailor from the left, at the top, is believed to be of Freddy Jackson. Jackson died a few days before the photo was taken by walking into a moving propeller.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image5-chyqednxjd.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"598\" /></strong></p><h2>The SS Watertown - 1924</h2><p>This image taken from the SS Watertown&nbsp;shows the faces of two crewmen, James Courtney and Michael Meehan in the water. The two men died while onboard the ship and were given a burial at sea.</p><p>Other crew members on the ship saw the faces in the water but didn't initially take photos, they went back to a similar spot and saw them again. Five of the six photos showed nothing, but this was the sixth and clearly shows the faces of two men.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image6-s3dpzirgbu.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"617\" /></strong></p><h2>The Brown Lady - 1936&nbsp;</h2><p>This photo of \"The Brown Lady\" is considered by many to be actual photographic evidence of ghosts. It was taken at Raynham Hall in Norfolk, England in 1936. There had allegedly been many sightings of the figure before this photo and it's said to be the ghost of Lady Townshend. She was locked in a room in the hall by her husband when he found out about her infidelity and left there to die.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image7-8jmaqxqdf2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"620\" /></strong></p><h2>Mrs Andrews&nbsp;baby - 1947</h2><p>This photo of a child appearing over a grave was taken by Mrs Andrews in 1947. She noticed the ghost when she had the film developed, but said it wasn't her daughter in the picture. Despite there being some graves for children nearby, the child in the picture has never been identified.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image8-yydlc5qmuj.jpg\" /></p><h2>An unexpected guest - 1950s</h2><p>This image, taken at some point in the 1950s shows a small family sitting at a table. Two boys sit happily on their mother's laps but a pretty terrifying and unexpected guest has also dropped in. Hanging disturbingly from the rafters.&nbsp;</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image9-jdsxfcq7zm.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"576\" /></strong></p><h2>Corroboree Rock - 1959</h2><p>Nobody knows who the ghostly figure in this photo is, but it was taken in Alice Springs, Northern Territory, Australia in 1959. Some people think it's just a case of a double exposure, while others think it could be a spirit watching us, or something else, because it looks like they're holding binoculars.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image10-en4n30mihv.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"421\" /></p><h2>The Back Seat Ghost - March 1959</h2><p>This photo was taken by Mabel Chinnery in 1959. It shows her husband in his car with,&nbsp;allegedly, her dead mother-in-law on the back seat. While paranormalists believe it to be real, others have debunked it as being another case of double exposure.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image11-zouxnyjfoa.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"580\" /></strong></p><h2>Newby Church&nbsp;- 1963</h2><p>Some analysts think this photo taken at Newby Church in North Yorkshire, England is a fake because the character looks to be posing too much. However, Reverend KF Lord insists there was nothing visible to the naked eye when he took the photo, and photo experts say it hasn't been double exposed.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image12-csdvorxgrs.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"540\" /></strong></p><h2>Tulip Staircase Ghost - 1966</h2><p>This photo taken inside the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, England, clearly shows a ghostly figure holding the handrail of the Tulip Staircase. Photo experts have all agreed that it hasn't been tampered with, so is considered a genuine example of ghosts' existence.&nbsp;</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image13-atujd9thik.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"479\" /></strong></p><h2>Robert A Ferguson - November 1968</h2><p>Because this photo was taken on a Polaroid, it's been deemed by many to be legitimate. It shows Robert A Ferguson giving a speech, with the ghost of his deceased brother Walter peering over him.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image14-ms7zaqibxb.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"443\" /></strong></p><h2>Worstead Church - 1975</h2><p>Peter Berthelot took this picture of his wife, Diane, sitting on a pew at the Worstead Church in Norfolk, England in 1975. When they had the film developed, they noticed a ghost sitting on the pew behind Diane. A man allegedly stayed in the church all night sometime in 1830 to try and disprove the theory of ghosts, but he claimed the following morning he had in fact seen the white lady seen in this picture.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image15-kflwqgkcvt.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"576\" /></p><h2>Amityville&nbsp;Ghost - 1976</h2><p>This photo, taken by Ed and Lorraine Warren, claims to show the ghost of nine-year-old John DeFeo. DeFeo, along with his other brother, two sisters and parents, were killed by his older brother Ronald at their house in Amityville.</p><p>Ed and Lorraine Warren were paranormal experts who entered the house and captured this image using a camera that consistently took infrared photos during the night.</p><p>The DeFeo murders were the inspiration for The Amityville Horror books and films.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image16-wzhld16cba.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"541\" /></strong></p><h2>Toys 'R' Us - 1978</h2><p>The Toys 'R' Us store in Sunnyvale, California is allegedly haunted by the ghost of Johnny Johnson, and this image shows a silhouette leaning up against the shelves. The same figure wasn't there when the photo was taken.</p><p>The story goes that Johnny had a thing for a girl named Elizabeth, the daughter of a plantation owner - the plantation used to be on the Toys 'R' Us site. Johnny bled to death after cutting himself chopping wood, and now roams the aisles of the store searching for her. Or Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image17-zf9xkly6ng.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"520\" /></p><h2>St Botolph's Church - 1982</h2><p>If you look carefully in the upper right-hand corner of this photo, you can just make out a translucent figure. It was taken at St Boltoph's Church in 1982 and, at the time, there were only three people in the building. A builder later contacted Chris Brackley, who took the photo, to tell him he recognised the face as being the same as someone he'd previously seen in a coffin in the church.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image18-3aby5ngtvw.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"489\" /></strong></p><h2>Coventry&nbsp;Spectre - 1985</h2><p>At first glance, you'd think there's nothing wrong with this photo. But look again, and you'll see a tall, dark figure wearing what could be a monk's frock, with a hood, in the top left. This is a photo of the Coventry Freeman society showing everyone at the event, including the mysterious figure, bowing their heads. Nobody at the event was seen wearing that style of clothing.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image19-s5m7rdcekb.jpg\" /></p><h2>The ghost pilot</h2><p>In 1987, Mrs Sayer was visiting air airfield in England with her friend. She thought it would fun to take a photo of her sitting in the cockpit.</p><p>When the image was developed, there was a man sitting in the pilot's seat who hadn't been there when the photo was taken. A long lost pilot? No one is sure.&nbsp;</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image20-u9meaedn4g.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"510\" /></strong></p><h2>Pawling Fire Department - 1988</h2><p>The white figure in this photo is believed to be some sort of angel, overlooking Rose Benvenuto, who was involved in the car crash. She said it could only have taken a miracle for her to survive the crash, and lo and behold, there's an angel-like figure in&nbsp;attending firefighter Sharon Boo's photo.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image21-pzknorbjty.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"564\" /></strong></p><h2>Madonna&nbsp;of Bachelor's Grove - 1991</h2><p>The Ghost Research Society of America took this photo at Bachelor's Cemetery in Illinois, after it noticed strange readings on its&nbsp;equipment. Researchers&nbsp;didn't see anything at the time, but when this image was exposed, it showed a woman in white clothing sitting on one of the graves.&nbsp;</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image22-ykq0og6vvu.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"527\" /></strong></p><h2>The Wem Town Hall Ghost - November 1995</h2><p>Although Tony O'Rahilly's photo appears to show&nbsp;the ghost of a young girl in&nbsp;the doorway to a burning down Wem Town Hall, it was later deemed to be a fake. The girl in question apparently appears on a postcard that appeared in the local paper.&nbsp;</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image23-9ypwokhexm.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"539\" /></strong></p><h2>Boot Hill Ghost - 1996</h2><p>Only Ike Canton's friend was seen when this photo was taken, The mysterious man wearing a hat behind him wasn't. Canton later looked more closely at the photo and decided the figure was, in fact, holding a knife, with the point ending just above his collar.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image24-contmvwndc.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"498\" /></strong></p><h2>Grandpa's Ghost - August 1997</h2><p>Denise Russell took this photo of her grandma, who lived alone at the time, on 17 August 1997. Even though the photo had been developed, copied and given to other family members, nobody noticed the male figure standing over her until Christmas Day 2000. The Russell family say it's a spitting image of their grandpa who died in 1984.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image25-shcjfqqgr8.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"529\" /></strong></p><h2>Sefton Church - 1999</h2><p>This picture at Sefton Church in Liverpool, England, clearly shows a man wearing a black uniform, believed to be the old church minister. There were allegedly only two photographers in the church on the day it was taken, and neither of them recall seeing a physical being standing there when the photo was taken.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image26-gzyte6y80r.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></p><h2>Girls in Manila - 2000's</h2><p>The two girls in this photo, taken in Manila, Philippines, didn't report seeing anyone or feeling any presence when this photo was taken. It was also taken on a digital camera, so it can't have been the result of double exposure.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image27-gh2zdouor0.png\" /></p><h2>Waverly Hills Sanatorium - 2006</h2><p>This image was snapped in an abandoned tuberculosis hospital in Louisville, Kentucky in 2006. As you can imagine, in its heyday, the hospital saw an incredible amount of sickness and death - leading many to believe in the possibility that it could be haunted.</p><p>In recent years, it has become one of&nbsp;America's most popular&nbsp;destinations for ghost-hunters.</p><p>This eerie image apparently depicts&nbsp;Mary Lee, a nurse who hung herself in the hospital. The story goes that this poor woman was&nbsp;impregnated by a doctor who worked in the hospital but&nbsp;later wanted nothing to do with her.</p><p><strong><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image28-swo3y9qzrt.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"561\" /></strong></p><h2>Tewin Bury Farm Ghost - 2008</h2><p>Neil Sandwich took this photo of a farmhouse where his friends were getting married. When he put the photo into Photoshop and adjusted the exposure, he noticed a mysterious white figure on the right-hand side, appearing to be peering out of a doorway. Cleaners at the farmhouse had apparently seen the ghost of a young boy wearing white clothes before, too.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image29-p1rtly6iob.jpg\" /></p><h2>San Antonio crossing ghosts</h2><p>Years ago, sometime in the 1930s, it's said that a school bus full of children broke down near a railway crossing in San Antonio, Texas. Tragically, a speeding train hit the bus, killing several children and the bus driver.&nbsp;</p><p>This photo taken by&nbsp;Andy and Debi Chesney appears to show some ghostly apparitions that people have suggested look like ghosts of the children. Like any of these images, there is some debate about whether they're real and even if the history itself is true, but they're still spooky.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image1-b6jvpra9hg.jpg\" /></p><h2>A ghostly pooch</h2><p>This photo shows a tale of two four-legged friends. The dog on the left had a much larger pal (pictured on the right). When the little one died, he was later photographed seemingly appearing with his friend from beyond the spirit world.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image1-oqtgnyfvyv.jpg\" /></p><h2>A demonic spirit on a hospital bed</h2><p>This weird vision shows a CCTV camera in a hospital. A demonic spirit appears to be trampling over the bed. Apparently the person in the bed passed away shortly afterwards. This image could easily appear in our list of <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/141531-29-of-the-most-famous-alien-and-monster-photographs-ever-taken\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"follow noopener\">the most famous monster photographs instead</a>.&nbsp;</p> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 30 Apr 2020 15:20:00 +0000","feedId":7639,"bgimg":"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image1-ksgkjn7rfa.jpg?v1","linkMd5":"787a41be00ce83b4b3e2ef5288ebac2e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn79@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-51-962_1c9441633b90ac67.webp","destWidth":748,"destHeight":580,"sourceBytes":88601,"destBytes":50782,"author":"Max Langridge","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image1-ksgkjn7rfa.jpg?v1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn79@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-51-962_1c9441633b90ac67.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image2-kq6fowhz8n.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn58@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-10-445_a31dfcdb0608908d.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image3-a1ozzfjca8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn73@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-11-677_cf6a08bc2022b2bd.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image4-nvr7q2bxhl.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn88@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-17-614_454ee6db67b58cc7.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image5-chyqednxjd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn58@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-12-049_bc11413dae628108.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image6-s3dpzirgbu.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn83@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-18-432_37f65c1e372aa756.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image7-8jmaqxqdf2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn88@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-37-16-790_039056feb930248a.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image8-yydlc5qmuj.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn27@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-36-58-837_0bb475b48e2e9b73.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image9-jdsxfcq7zm.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn75@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-36-53-970_aa6b6c76eed5e5c0.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image10-en4n30mihv.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn23@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-18-766_39f536fd0e88049d.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image11-zouxnyjfoa.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn93@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-37-12-564_e65bb39005b15e7c.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image12-csdvorxgrs.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn85@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-03-497_030625d896f0ea8d.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image13-atujd9thik.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn12@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-56-254_1f39da1615fde6c0.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image14-ms7zaqibxb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn7@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-20-219_7b41064cf0c800fa.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image15-kflwqgkcvt.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-37-17-898_922d5ed108954cef.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image16-wzhld16cba.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn61@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-10-501_f1e9a68737912c68.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image17-zf9xkly6ng.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn46@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-37-05-596_c3d32914328d3a73.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image18-3aby5ngtvw.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn68@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-02-425_4f359ab20dc13ebc.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image19-s5m7rdcekb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn31@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-27-022_c429a9833222c6ff.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image20-u9meaedn4g.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn62@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-03-172_9684442fc090d55e.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image21-pzknorbjty.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn53@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-08-121_ffd98ed91dc18ecb.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image22-ykq0og6vvu.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn45@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-11-981_24b37b233110c802.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image23-9ypwokhexm.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn33@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-22-341_37668d84bc7a4e3b.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image24-contmvwndc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn5@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-01-886_c27a56be0e926259.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image25-shcjfqqgr8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn37@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-10-389_ba932a68caad8317.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image26-gzyte6y80r.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn22@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-01-061_e7551ea66858f201.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image27-gh2zdouor0.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn31@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-56-435_c5754802808076b3.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-news-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image28-swo3y9qzrt.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn46@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-13-882_dae5896d58f4665a.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image29-p1rtly6iob.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn29@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-37-07-997_bd21ab30178e2d19.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image1-b6jvpra9hg.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn82@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-01-734_2cd3e72b87c903ba.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141224-cameras-feature-the-most-famous-ghost-photographs-ever-taken-image1-oqtgnyfvyv.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn79@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-58-177_748ee6eb0339ad8b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209019},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"Stunning underwater photos that will take your breath away","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/147200-astounding-underwater-photos","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"499\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-14-astounding-underwater-photos-image1-70otgbrzfk.jpg?v1\"> <p>There’s something magical about underwater photos. If you don’t believe us, imagine Nirvana’s Nevermind cover with the baby lying on a rug instead of swimming in a pool.</p><p>Stock photo libraries are packed with thrilling underwater shots, but there are lots of gems on Flickr, in Wikimedia and in other libraries too, and you can often use those photos in your own creations too.</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/drones/news/145720-astounding-aerial-photos-or-amazing-abstract-art\" rel=\"follow\">Astounding aerial photos or amazing abstract art?</a></li> \n </ul><p>Here are some of the most astounding underwater photos we’ve seen; some are astounding because of the moment they captured; others because of the stories of their subjects, and still others because of what they say about what we humans have done to so many species.</p><p>Please note that the last photo may not be appropriate for younger viewers.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image7-7qxno5rxvj.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Polar Bear</h2><p>Not everything you see underwater lives underwater. Visitors like this polar bear are bad news for seals, because they’re looking for their dinner: for many seals this face may be the last thing they see, as it’s attached to a body weighing as much as 450Kg. Polar bears are yet another species suffering because of humans: climate change is destroying the ice on which they live, and they were classified as a threatened species by the US in 2008.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image10-qdparrkatu.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1067\" /></p><h2>Grey Shark</h2><p>Greek-based photographer has made good use of colour in this photo of a grey shark: it looks a lot more sinister than it actually is, because the grey shark isn’t really dangerous to humans unless you wear a swimsuit made of raw meat. Like many marine photographs this one has a sad undercurrent, because like many sharks the grey shark is suffering from declining numbers after years of commercial fishing: while they’re protected species, illegal fishing still occurs.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image2-nljsk14rbe.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Humboldt Penguin</h2><p>Guichard is from London, but you won’t see many Humboldts around there: it’s native to South America, although this particular shot was taken in a bird park in France. You probably guessed that from the background colour: underwater shots in relatively small enclosures tend to be much greener than ones taken in the great outdoors. Nevertheless it’s a superb shot, capturing some really excellent side-eye from its subject.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image1-kf10u9wnd4.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Blue Dragon-Glaucus Atlanticus</h2><p>Technically this photo is only slightly underwater, as its subject was washed up into a rock pool –&nbsp;but we’re including it because it’s a great example of how otherworldly so many marine creatures can be. This little blue beauty is better known as a sea swallow, blue sea slug or Lizard Nudibranch, which would be an excellent stage name for someone in a band. It’s a small, blue sea slug that floats upside down in water; the blue colouring is camouflage so that it blends in with the blue of water, while the underwater side is silvery-grey. Don’t pick one up if you see one: they deliver a very painful sting.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image5-1rt9t5r8qf.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Seal Underwater</h2><p>The NOAA is the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the scientific agency that concentrates on the oceans and the atmosphere. Its Flickr feed is full of amazing images like this one, taken on Hawaii’s Pearl and Hermes reef. We love it because it captures the playful curiosity of the seal really well. This particular seal is a young monk seal, one of two remaining types of monk seal: the third, the Caribbean monk seal, is extinct. This chap is a Hawaiian monk seal, the only seal native to Hawaii and sadly yet another name on the endangered species list.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image3-mnbwajchf7.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Humpback Whale</h2><p>This beautiful photo of a humpback whale inspecting a diver is all over the internet –&nbsp;and sadly it’s usually posted without credit on wallpaper sites, free photo sites and so on. Once again we’re in the good hands of the NOAA, and this photo helps communicate the scale and majesty of this extraordinary creature. Some humpbacks can grow as long as 16 metres and weigh up to 30 metric tons, which is all the more incredible when you hit YouTube for videos of them hurling themselves into the air. This is one creature you really don’t want belly flopping onto your pedal.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image11-jf2bu8nwct.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>A Magnificent Siphonophore</h2><p>If we didn’t trust the NOAA we’d think they’d made this one in a 3D modelling app. The wondrously coloured Siphonophore is a Cnidaria, which is a group of creatures that includes coral and jellyfish such as the infamous Portuguese Man O’ War, and some of them are incredibly big: specimens as long as 40 metres have been discovered. The most colourful ones live in the deepest waters and some are even bioluminescent, glowing when disturbed. They’re predators but they’re also very vulnerable as they break very easily.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image13-mvhtiuqzw8.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Underwater Woman</h2><p>Let’s have some art. This striking image by Engin Akyurt is our favourite in a series of underwater shots: we like the composition, the stillness of the model and the contrast between the deep black of the background and the bright red of the model’s dress. Stock photo libraries contain quite a few arty underwater shots – for example, Adobe Stock has a selection of women in brightly coloured clothes and of couples swimming while wearing formal clothes –&nbsp;but we prefer this one: it does more with less.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-14-astounding-underwater-photos-image1-70otgbrzfk.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Purple and Pink Jellyfish</h2><p>Aren’t jellyfish weird? This could be a space alien, or the pattern made by something leaking ink into water. It’s a brilliantly colourful image by the very versatile Tim Mossholder, whose photos often make great use of colour as in this photo. We don’t know what particular species this jellyfish is, but the combination of purple and pink usually spells bad news for its prey and of any humans unlucky enough to get too close.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image14-ru5aazfu8g.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Scuba Diver near Brown Turtle</h2><p>We love all photos of turtles because of their fantastically unimpressed expressions, but we particularly like this one because Tom Fisk’s use of perspective makes it look like the diver is approaching a turtle that’s much bigger than he is. The picture was shot off Komodo Island in Indonesia, which is home to five species of sea turtles –&nbsp;and while this particular turtle isn’t a giant, they can grow up to 2m long and can weigh up to 590kg.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image6-hfyjpsrykc.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Pink and Brown Jellyfish</h2><p>Kalisinski has taken some beautiful shots in the warm, clear waters around Mallorca, and this close shot of an otherworldly jellyfish is great: it’s captured not just the weird blobbiness of its subject but the floating tendrils it uses to catch its meals. Although Kalisinski doesn’t name the jellyfish we think it’s Pelagia Noctiluca, a relatively small and quite unusual sight in the Majorcan waters but one you don’t want to get on the wrong side of: those tentacles can cause pain, burning and muscle cramps.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image9-qbemfov05q.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Red Jellyfish</h2><p>There’s weird, and then there’s Red Jellyfish weird. This luminous lovely looks like a visitor from another planet, and we’d love to know who took the photo, where they took it and what particular kind of jellyfish this is. Sadly Pixabay can only tell us that it was shot in 2013 on a Panasonic DMC-FZ200, which isn’t really very helpful.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image4-ivbjitgjy2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Man in Water</h2><p>Who needs extraordinary creatures when you can get a scuba diver to blow some bubbles from his mask? This unattributed shot from Pixabay works brilliantly because it’s free of context: we can make up the entire backstory and imagine he’s a spy, or he’s just spotted a really big and angry shark.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image12-z4ezldg1mr.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Isla Mujeres</h2><p>There’s something haunting about man-made things that weren’t designed to live at the bottom of the sea, and the photo sites are packed with fascinating photos of shipwrecks and other vehicles that ended up where they weren’t intended. But as interesting as they are, we’re more drawn to the ruins of architecture and of amazing things like these sunken statues from the Mexican island of Isla Mujeres. It looks like the aftermath of a tragedy but it’s actually a modern art museum, which is pretty astounding.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-stunning-underwater-photos-that-will-take-your-breath-away-image15-ng9u387pak.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"459\" /></p><h2>Sea Turtle in fishing net</h2><p>Our final photograph is the saddest: taken by Greenpeace photographer Salvatore Barbera, aka Capitan Giona, it’s the body of a turtle drowned by a fishing net. While much fishing is of course environmentally responsible it still has its victims, and illegal overfishing has brought some species to the very brink of extinction. But it’s not just fishing that threatens marine life. Pollution, especially in the form of plastics, is taking a heavy toll too.</p>\n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/drones/news/133911-best-drone-photos-ever-stunning-images-taken-from-up-high\" rel=\"follow\">Best drone photos ever: Stunning images taken from the sky</a></li> \n </ul> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 25 Apr 2020 08:03:00 +0000","feedId":7639,"bgimg":"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/147200-cameras-feature-14-astounding-underwater-photos-image1-70otgbrzfk.jpg?v1","linkMd5":"3d8caeef3681e254ed510e32b65fa9e6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn55@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-36-52-459_60a7b98545920fee.webp","destWidth":748,"destHeight":499,"sourceBytes":58763,"destBytes":24260,"author":"Carrie
