5-yklprow2rd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn11@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-36-57-881_1aa240b4b2a71ab6.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141531-cameras-feature-unexplained-mysteries-and-paranormal-events-image26-mgdsxvbvgc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn35@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-36-59-467_8d1330dfb9d2f4b2.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141531-cameras-feature-unexplained-mysteries-and-paranormal-events-image27-yrtlviscpd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn27@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-37-06-243_3792ff32d9a73117.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141531-cameras-feature-unexplained-mysteries-and-paranormal-events-image28-tpdelnigcr.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn61@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-23-738_78a52fb0d1cf3e08.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141531-cameras-feature-unexplained-mysteries-and-paranormal-events-image29-l8ykojd4qq.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn97@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-10-214_b3044bfc3ef87e20.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141531-cameras-feature-unexplained-mysteries-and-paranormal-events-image30-bx8lubysdg.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn98@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-22-104_f0a71e73c3bb05b1.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/141531-cameras-feature-unexplained-mysteries-and-paranormal-events-image1-73rfnahwui.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn71@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-37-14-841_4f92c8ca780d8000.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209019},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"Best camera for vlogging? Panasonic G100 vs Sony ZV-1 vs Canon G7 X III","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/buyers-guides/152639-best-vlogging-camera-panasonic-g100-sony-zv1-canon-g7x3","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"498\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/152639-cameras-news-feature-panasonic-g100-vs-sony-zv-1-vs-canon-g7-x-iii-image1-g2ad3ntokw.jpg?v1\"> <p>Traditional camera makers are shooting to become king for an expanding market sector: vlogging cameras. Where YouTube is king, more makers are looking for better ways to capture themselves and their surroundings in better quality.</p><p>We pick three of the best options out there - the <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/panasonic/152607-panasonic-lumix-g100-mirrorless-vlogging-face-voice\" rel=\"\">Panasonic Lumix G100</a>, <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/sony/152309-sony-zv-1-review\" rel=\"\">Sony Vlog Camera ZV-1</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/reviews/canon/148530-canon-powershot-g7-x-iii-review-3-camera-video\" rel=\"\">Canon Powershot G7 X III</a> - to help you decide which makes best sense to buy and why.</p><p>squirrel_widget_270682</p><h2>Size &amp; Portability</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>Panasonic Lumix G100: 115.6 x 82.5 x 54.2mm; 412g (with 12-42mm lens)</li> \n  <li>Sony Vlog Camera ZV-1: 105.5 x 60 x 43.5mm; 294g&nbsp;</li> \n  <li>Canon PowerShot G7 X M3: 105.5 x 60.9 x 41.4mm; 304g</li> \n </ul><p>Small is sometimes mightiest. While all three of these cameras are small, it's the Sony that will most likely feel lightest and most portable. There's not a huge amount in it.</p><h2>Sensor Size &amp; Lens</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>Panasonic Lumix G100 \n   <ul> \n    <li>Sensor: 20MP Micro Four Thirds</li> \n    <li>Lens: Interchangeable lens mount \n     <ul> \n      <li>12-32mm kit lens (24-64mm equivalent)</li> \n     </ul> </li> \n   </ul> </li> \n  <li>Sony Vlog Camera ZV-1 \n   <ul> \n    <li>Sensor: 20MP 1.0-inch Exmor RS CMOS</li> \n    <li>Lens: 24-70mm f/1.8-2.8 equivalent</li> \n   </ul> </li> \n  <li>Canon PowerShot G7 X M3 \n   <ul> \n    <li>Sensor: 20.1MP 1.0-inch stacked CMOS</li> \n    <li>Lens: 24-100mm f/1.8-2.8 equivalent</li> \n   </ul> </li> \n </ul><p>However, there's a big reason for the variance in size: sensor size and each lens' focal length.</p><p>Both Sony and Canon models have fixed-in-place zoom lenses, while Panasonic's G100 is a system camera with interchangeable Micro Four Thirds lenses - which makes it potentially much more versatile (and a bit larger and heavier by comparison).</p><p>All three of these cameras house sensors that are larger than an entry-level compact, which bodes well for quality. The Sony and Canon both use stacked 1-inch size CMOS sensors. The Panasonic has the larger scale sensor, however, which ought to mean greater potential when it comes to background blur and overall quality.</p><p>The kit Panasonic G100 comes with a 12-32mm pancake zoom - which delivers a 24-64mm equivalent zoom. That's the same on the wide-angle as the 24-70mm of the Sony ZV-1 and the 24-100mm of the Canon G7 X III. Note that the Canon can zoom the furthest - i.e. make farther away subjects look closer-up in the frame.</p><h2>Audio, Mic Input</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>Panasonic Lumix G100: OZO Audio by Nokia (audio tracking / positioning), 3.5mm mic input, micro HDMI out</li> \n  <li>Sony Vlog Camera ZV-1: 3.5mm mic input, micro HDMI out, deadcat wind-shield included</li> \n  <li>Canon PowerShot G7 X M3: 3.5mm mic input, micro HDMI out</li> \n </ul><p>A big reason to buy a dedicated camera for video is for its audio abilities. All three of these cameras offer a 3.5mm microphone input, so you can connect an accessory microphone as you please - whether that's a directional shotgun mic, a wireless mounted mic, or any other number of possibilities.</p><p>However, you won't necessarily always want to use a microphone. It's here that Sony comes up trumps by including what's called a deadcat in the box - a fluffy microphone cover that sits up top and stops wind noise from creating those 'tearing' sounds.</p><p>The most advanced of the lot, however, is Panasonic's Lumix G100. For the first time in a camera this includes OZO Audio by Nokia, which utilises the three onboard microphones to record in a directional format - you can define whether you want behind, in front, or subject tracked to be sound isolated. That's the real big winner: the system's autofocus includes face detection which can be audio synched, so as the subject moves through the frame the OZO tech will use the right proportion of microphones to channel that audio isolation. Very clever.</p><p>squirrel_widget_254445</p><h2>Screen &amp; Viewfinder</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>Panasonic Lumix G100: 3-inch 1,840k-dot vari-angle touchscreen LCD; built-in 3,680k-dot EVF</li> \n  <li>Sony Vlog Camera ZV-1: 3-inch 921k-dot vari-angle touchscreen LCD; no EVF</li> \n  <li>Canon PowerShot G7 X M3: 3-inch 1,040k-dot vertical tilt-angle touchscreen LCD; no EVF</li> \n </ul><p>Traditional cameras aren't great for vlogging on account of their fixed screens. All three of these cameras, however, offer mounted LCD screens that can be repositioned: the Canon's flips forward vertically; the Sony's and Panasonic's are side-mounted and therefore offer even more versatile position potential.&nbsp;</p><p>In terms of screen resolution the Panasonic is far and away the most resolute - although at arm's length we doubt you'll notice a huge difference in this, and actually more dots on screen is just more of a battery drain.</p><p>Of the three cameras only the Panasonic has a built-in electronic viewfinder (EVF). This is more for shooting still images or shielding from sunlight to better judge exposure and composition - so certainly has its use cases.</p><h2>Video Credentials</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>All models: Up to 4K at 30fps \n   <ul> \n    <li>Panasonic: Up to 9mins 59secs</li> \n    <li>Sony: Up to 5mins due to avoid overheating</li> \n    <li>Canon: Up to 9mins 59secs</li> \n   </ul> </li> \n  <li>Panasonic Lumix G100: 1080p at 60fps (29m 59s maximum)</li> \n  <li>Sony Vlog Camera ZV-1: 1080p at 120fps (29m 59s maximum)</li> \n  <li>Canon PowerShot G7 X M3: 1080p at 120fps (29m 59s maximum)</li> \n </ul><p>Being vlogging targeted, all three cameras cater for 4K resolution at 30fps maximum (and with 100Mbps in all cases, ensuring there's enough data for optimum quality). However, the Sony can only record for half the time compared to the other two to avoid overheating - and even then the Canon and Panasonic max out at 10 minutes at this resolution.</p><p>If you're looking for Full HD recording to up your recording time, save on bandwidth, storage space, and editing processing pressures then all three cameras can cater for that too.</p><p>Slow-motion is best handled by the Sony, with Full HD at 240fps/480fps/960fps available. The Canon offers 120fps slow-motion. The Panasonic's spec sheet says 120fps sensor output is possible too - but that in-camera capture is 60fps.</p><h2>Stabilisation</h2>\n <ul> \n  <li>Panasonic Lumix G100: 5-axis hybrid stabilisation (4-axis for 4K video)</li> \n  <li>Sony Vlog Camera ZV-1: Steadyshot for Movie hybrid stabilisation</li> \n  <li>Canon PowerShot G7 X M3: 5-axis Advanced Dynamic IS &amp; Auto Level</li> \n </ul><p>Stabilisation is important when it comes to video. Although you may wish to buy a handheld gimbal for extra stabilisation for those ultra-smooth video results.</p><p>All three cameras offer hybrid stabilisation systems - that's to say there's optical lens-shift working in tandem with electronic stabilisation (using a portion of the sensor as a buffer to counter motion). We've not tested these three side by side so can't say which is best of the bunch.</p><p>squirrel_widget_160674</p><h2>Conclusion</h2><p>The big question: which one to choose? Well, if price comes into the equation then the Sony is the priciest of the lot. That might be a bit of a surprise when the Panasonic offers a more advanced audio isolation system, has a larger sensor size, and interchangeable lenses.</p><p>If size is your biggest concern then the Sony is the lightest of the bunch, which helps in terms of portability. It's also got the most muscle when it comes to slow-motion options - although its 4K capture is more time-limited than the other two.</p><p>The decision, as they say, is yours.</p> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 24 Jun 2020 11:01:00 +0000","feedId":7639,"bgimg":"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/152639-cameras-news-feature-panasonic-g100-vs-sony-zv-1-vs-canon-g7-x-iii-image1-g2ad3ntokw.jpg?v1","linkMd5":"c47d8013ed60744c71e770a94ebc13d7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn35@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-50-613_098180e6419e9918.webp","destWidth":748,"destHeight":498,"sourceBytes":50147,"destBytes":29002,"author":"Mike Lowe","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/152639-cameras-news-feature-panasonic-g100-vs-sony-zv-1-vs-canon-g7-x-iii-image1-g2ad3ntokw.jpg?v1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn35@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-36-50-613_098180e6419e9918.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209017},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"Amazing images of our moon in all shapes and sizes","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/147588-amazing-images-of-our-moon","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"499\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/147588-cameras-feature-amazing-images-of-our-moon-in-all-shapes-and-sizes-image1-bruv1hpm4j.jpg?v1\"> <p>It's now over 50 years since the human race went to the moon with the first moon landing by Apollo 11 happening on 20 July 1969. And with NASA's <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/topics/moon-to-mars\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ongoing plans</a> to land on the moon again by 2024, we thought what better way to celebrate than with a collection of some of the best photos of the moon in all its glory for you to enjoy.&nbsp;</p>\n <ul>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.pocket-lint.com/cameras/news/147538-staggering-images-of-mars\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"follow noopener\">Staggering images of Mars like you've never seen before</a></li>\n </ul><p>Enjoy the range of inspiring&nbsp;images of our moon in all shapes and sizes:</p> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 18 Aug 2020 12:10:00 +0000","feedId":7639,"bgimg":"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/147588-cameras-feature-amazing-images-of-our-moon-in-all-shapes-and-sizes-image1-bruv1hpm4j.jpg?v1","linkMd5":"e0c667e879c3cde6c24e73dfb89fa708","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn92@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-36-50-648_33f1ed8cb15d0572.webp","destWidth":748,"destHeight":499,"sourceBytes":33335,"destBytes":16432,"author":"Adrian Willings","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/147588-cameras-feature-amazing-images-of-our-moon-in-all-shapes-and-sizes-image1-bruv1hpm4j.jpg?v1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn92@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-36-50-648_33f1ed8cb15d0572.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209023},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"LiteChaser is a complete camera filter system for the iPhone 11","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/phones/news/151357-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpro-s-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"499\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image1-kr5qgscogd.jpg?v1\"> <p>It's a bit of a given that phone cameras have been getting better and better in recent years, to the point where you can potentially now take professional-quality photos and videos with your smartphone.</p><p>That's well and true, but you might, like us, find that your snaps still come out looking distinctly average a lot of the time. Often, that's because, while the camera might be powerful, the lighting conditions might not be quite right, or your hand might be shaking a tiny bit, or any number of other reasons. Enter the likes of PolarPro, which makes amazing attachments for your smartphone to level up your mobile photography.&nbsp;</p><p>It's got a new range of accessories dropping for the iPhone 11 and 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max - <a href=\"https://www.polarprofilters.com/pages/litechaser-pro\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">LiteChaser Pro</a>, which will take your photos and video up a notch, and we wanted to run you through just what benefits you could reap from picking them up. If you think a&nbsp;complete filter system for iPhone 11 could improve your photography, read on.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image2-s7crxdgcpi.jpg\" /></p><h2>Get a grip</h2><p>The core part of PolarPro's LiteChaser system is a case for your phone, which unlocks its potential by allowing you to clip on various other accessories. In itself, though, it's a great bit of protection that looks nice and sleek, and won't draw attention to itself when you're not in the middle of shooting.&nbsp;</p><p>The case lets you clip on LiteChaser filters over the phone's camera unit (more on those later). It also lets you clip on an adjustable grip unit for better handling.</p><p>The grip is perfect for making sure that you're in control of your shot at all times, but it's even got its own secrets. You can use it to mount your phone&nbsp;on most tripods - a package that'll see you converting your iPhone into your 'A' camera in no time.&nbsp;</p><h2><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image3-t0iktufomj.jpg\" /></h2><h2>Mount it</h2><p>That mounting option means that you can really use your phone in a myriad of ways - you might want it on a tripod, or you might want it handheld, but the grip is great regardless. A low-profile rail means that you can position it wherever you need on the back of the phone, plus you can easily rotate it into a portrait position if you're shooting in vertical.</p><p>Plus, there's even a mount on top of the grip, too, which is perfect for connecting microphones or lights which will even further elevate your shooting toward the sort of performance previously reserved for DSLR cameras.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image4-kgpds18vfx.jpg\" /></p><h2>ND filters and polarizer</h2><p>Of course, in many ways the heart of PolarPro's system is its filters, and there are three superb options available for the iPhone 11, iPhone 11 Pro and iPhone 11 Pro Max.&nbsp;PolarPro wanted to take what they were known for, their prestigious line of filters, and adapt it to a mobile system. Precision light control is essential when creating high-end content, which is why PolarPro custom-engineered a line of filters to be compatible with LiteChaser Pro.&nbsp;</p><h4>ND8 (3-Stop) &amp; ND64 (8-Stop)</h4><p>These neutral density filters will make sure that you're getting the right amount of light through to your lenses, and give your footage a more professional feel, ready for cinematic-style edits.&nbsp;</p><h4>Variable ND (3-5 Stop)</h4><p>This little filter is an easy way into top-level shooting, letting you switch up how much light you're letting in on the fly so that you can shoot at lower framerates. That'll leave your content looking like you shot it with way more equipment.&nbsp;</p><h4>Circular Polarizer</h4><p>As a simple one-stop way to reduce issues in your footage, whether they're glare-related, haze or reflections, this polarizer will see you capturing deeper colours, and is a great way to really easily improve your output.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image5-balml5kz4e.jpg\" /></p><h2>Adaptability</h2><p>That range of filters, combined with the grip and case, means that you have access to a system that can adapt to any and all needs. Whether you're shooting handheld footage in low light, or setting up a timelapse shot with a tripod, you can do it all without needing to rig up special systems for yourself.&nbsp;</p><p>Plus, with an additional lens caps and the protection of the case, you don't have to worry about everything being massively delicate - it's a set of equipment built to be actually used, not wrapped up in bubble wrap.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image6-xprzh1yrax.jpg\" /></p><h2>Sustainability</h2><p>Finally, though, we always love it when smaller businesses make sure to think about their impact on the planet, and PolarPro is doing just that. Whether it's refining its package to minimize single-use plastics, or ensuring that its products have long lifespans and can be better recycled, the business is taking steps that we value.&nbsp;</p><p>It's got a carbon-offsetting system set up to make itself carbon neutral, too, which means that you can invest in the <a href=\"https://www.polarprofilters.com/pages/litechaser-pro\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">LiteChaser Pro</a> system without any guilty conscience.&nbsp;</p> </img>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 19 Mar 2020 17:00:00 +0000","feedId":7639,"bgimg":"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image1-kr5qgscogd.jpg?v1","linkMd5":"0828ce5c6e4c424a75072b8df8222b15","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn19@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-36-50-694_51fe0589d0924d98.webp","destWidth":748,"destHeight":499,"sourceBytes":56841,"destBytes":32442,"author":"Pocket-lint Promotion","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image1-kr5qgscogd.jpg?v1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn19@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-36-50-694_51fe0589d0924d98.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image2-s7crxdgcpi.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn76@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-15-625_9d5a146bf26aba93.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image3-t0iktufomj.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn35@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-37-14-817_bb4f7b5669a8edd6.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image4-kgpds18vfx.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn38@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-37-05-725_ddc4ab097329bc6b.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image5-balml5kz4e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn91@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-36-54-026_56c89e42debf5188.webp","https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/151357-phones-news-upgrade-your-mobile-photography-with-polarpros-litechaser-for-the-iphone-11-image6-xprzh1yrax.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn100@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-36-59-374_f8429c7902a8949c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598312209021},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:36:49","title":"50 Incredible images of space like you've never seen before","link":"https://www.pocket-lint.com/apps/news/142413-50-incredible-images-of-space-like-you-ve-never-seen-before","description":"<img width=\"748\" height=\"528\" src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/748x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image1-iha6vzu3wk.jpg?v1\"> <p>Space is an amazing place. Mankind has dreamt of exploring the distant edges of the Universe since we first set foot on the moon. Yet most of it remains far from our grasp and we&nbsp;can only dream of the delights and wonders beyond our reach.&nbsp;</p><p>Despite that, NASA's probes, long-range satellites and super telescopes have seen many of the interesting things out there - stars, black holes, other planets. There's an incredible place up there in the stars.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>For years now, space organisations like NASA have commissioned artists to create representations of the wonders beyond the stars aimed at exciting the average layman to the possibility of space exploration.</p><p>We've rounded up 50 amazing images that show what could be out there in the vastness of space and just how astonishingly beautiful the Universe could be.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image51-tbqa5hrfrc.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"900\" /></p><h2>Hot lava world</h2><p>This illustration shows what the hot, rocky exoplanet called 55 Cancri e could look like. Data from NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope shows that this planet,&nbsp;also referred to as the Lava world, has extreme temperature differences from one side of the planet to the other. The result of this is a large presence of lava pools across the surface.&nbsp;</p><p>55 Cancri e is twice as wide as Earth but has some similarities. For example, it's tidally locked, much like Earth but instead of a flowing ocean, the tides here are likely liquid lava.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image50-bn3rfvgyia.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1199\" /></p><h2>Exotic binary star system AR Scorpii</h2><p>This unique double star is made up of a quickly spinning white dwarf that sits close alongside its companion red dwarf. The spinning of the white dwarf powers electrons to near the speed of light, this reaction then releases radiation bursts that cause the entire system to pulse every couple of minutes. This pulsing can be seen from afar and crosses a wide range of the spectrums from ultraviolet to radio.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image49-jjgca2msyu.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"979\">&nbsp;</img></p><h2>Stars born in winds from supermassive black holes</h2><p>This artwork is inspired by data from ESO's&nbsp;Very Large Telescope which has observed stars forming from materials emanating from within supermassive black holes. An impressive sight indeed.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image48-x0iuty9gs8.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1131\" height=\"1600\" /></p><h2>The ultracool dwarf star TRAPPIST-1 from the surface of one of its planets</h2><p>40 light-years from Earth, three planets orbit an ultracool dwarf star. These planets were originally discovered using the&nbsp;TRAPPIST telescope at ESO’s La Silla Observatory and data shows they are likely to be similar in temperature and size to Earth and Venus.&nbsp;</p><p>This artistic impression imagines what the view from one of these planets might look like.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image47-t4cgqfpukn.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1000\" /></p><h2>The Gliese 667C system</h2><p>This image shows a theoretical example of the view from&nbsp;exoplanet Gliese 667Cd. With a view of the horizon showing the system's main star and two other stars located in the same solar system.&nbsp;</p><p>This solar system has been shown to have at least three planets lying in sufficient orbit from the stars to suggest the likelihood that water could exist on the surface and potential for the presence of life.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image46-bovfthmzrj.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1000\" /></p><h2>The rings around Chariklo</h2><p>Chariklo is a remote asteroid in the solar system. It's interestingly the smallest object in the system to have rings similar to those of Jupiter and Saturn. The asteroid is surrounded by two dense rings, the origin of which are unknown. This artist impression shows what the rings might look like from the surface of the asteroid.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image45-eptl2yov3a.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"965\" /></p><h2>The red supergiant star Antares&nbsp;</h2><p>ESO’s Very Large Telescope Interferometer&nbsp;has revealed detailed information about the red supergiant sun \"Antares\" from the Scorpius constellation. From it, astronomers have constructed the most detailed image ever made of any star besides our own.&nbsp; This artwork is based on that image and shows the velocity of the material within the atmosphere of the sun.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image44-ge5m4iauct.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1066\" /></p><h2>The surface of the dwarf planet Makemake</h2><p>Makemake is a distant dwarf planet that's two-thirds the size of Pluto and travels in an orbit around the sun that's further away than Pluto's orbit is too. This image shows an artist's impression of the surface of Makemake and how it may appear closer up.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image43-tbrchd0ode.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1120\" /></p><h2>Ultracool dwarf star TRAPPIST-1 from close to one of its planets</h2><p>This image is an impression of the potential view from one of the planets orbiting the ultracool dwarf star&nbsp;TRAPPIST-1. As one of the most interesting collections of planets discovered so far as they hold the correct size and temperature necessary to sustain life.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image42-tvdbayr0do.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1066\" /></p><h2>Crowd of ice cores in the Kuiper Belt</h2><p>This artwork features an artist's impression of the Kuiper Belt that contains the ice cores of a multitude of comets. An impressive sight that you wouldn't want to fly a spaceship through.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image41-raxscz1yhp.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1417\" height=\"1600\" /></p><h2>Star factories in the distant Universe</h2><p>This image shows a distant galaxy with large bright clouds that are several hundred light-years in size. These cloudy regions of the galaxy show areas of active star formation, that are 100 times brighter than those in the Milky Way. This suggests that the star formations here are in their early life and much more active than those typically found in other local galaxies.&nbsp;</p><p>The wonder of the Universe and creation in action captured in a single beautiful image.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image40-5oujvyenr0.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"900\" /></p><h2>Triton</h2><p>Triton is Neptune's largest moon and is shown here with a view of our Sun along with a blue crescent from Neptune in the distance. The surface of the moon is shown to be much like our own, pockmarked with craters and impact damage from over the years as space debris strikes&nbsp;home.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image39-7tw6fn5mzj.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1200\" /></p><h2>A stellar black hole</h2><p>Observations from ESO's Very Large Telescope and NASA's Chandra X-ray telescope have shown this stellar black hole emanating two powerful jets of hot gas. The black hole is thought to be 1,000 light-years across and twice as large as well 10 times more powerful than any other known blackhole studied so far.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image38-bco5aqiqeu.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1066\" /></p><h2>A disc around a massive baby star</h2><p>This image shows the formation of a massive baby star, images of new stars like this have been captured by astronomers and shows flared discs highlighting their birth. The discs are thought to extend about 130 times the distance that Earth current sits from our own sun and have a mass similar to the star itself -&nbsp;20 times that of our Sun.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image37-swlvdct3pz.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1066\" /></p><h2>The dwarf planet Eris and its moon Dysnomia</h2><p>In the distance of this image, the dwarf planet Eris sits, covered in a frost likely formed from the remains of its atmosphere. Recent astronomical observations have shown that Eris is smaller than Pluto and much smaller than initially thought when it was first discovered.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image36-jmuhii5bvk.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1236\" /></p><h2>The fastest rotating star</h2><p>In one of the satellite galaxies of the Milky Way sits this whirling star. This&nbsp;massive, bright star known as VFTS 102 is the fastest rotating star known to man. It rotates at about two million kilometres per hour. This speed has forced the star into an unusual shape with a surrounding disc of&nbsp;hot plasma.</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image35-31xzywfwju.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1066\" /></p><h2>Sunset on the super-Earth world Gliese 667 Cc</h2><p>Astronomers&nbsp;believe that there are billions of planets like this orbiting red dwarf stars throughout the Milky Way. This image is meant to represent one of the rocky planets orbiting the red dwarf Gliese 667 C, which is part of a triple star system.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image34-woqtqp1azh.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1137\" /></p><h2>Artist's impression of a vampire star and its victim</h2><p>Research data from ESO’s Very Large Telescope suggests that the hottest and brightest stars through the Universe are often like this - two stars, close together regularly transferring mass from one another. These so-called vampire stars are known as O stars and are a fascinating phenomenon.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image33-3zezud7jkt.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1600\" /></p><h2>Ice water crystal</h2><p>In this image, a dying star is seen in the distance as it puts on a final fiery show before its death. In the foreground, an ice-water crystal is seen orbiting the very edge of the system.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image32-lcaoj17iqj.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"900\" /></p><h2>The free-floating planet CFBDSIR J214947.2-040308.9</h2><p>This light blue planet appears this way because it is only detectable via infrared. This is because it only gives off a faint glow in the vastness of space as it's one of only a few free-floating planets in the solar system. It does not orbit a star like normal planets and therefore does not reflect light in the normal way.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image31-wa1fi6trt3.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"900\" /></p><h2>Orion KL&nbsp;</h2><p>The Orion KL Nebula is an active star-forming region of space within the centre of a molecular cloud. This artist's impression shows the beauty and power of creation in a single colourful image.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image30-sb2na86mqt.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1134\" /></p><h2>The disc and gas streams around HD 142527</h2><p>The Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) captured and imaged the remnants of this exploded Supernova. The inner regions are highlighted red due to their cold nature. The colour of the outer rings is highly contrasted due to the inner region blasting with the outwards and hitting the gases previously ejected from the Supernova before its detonation.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image29-lva8fezw2i.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"946\" /></p><h3>The central bulge of the Milky Way</h3><p>This image shows how the Milky Way galaxy would look like from the outside looking in. It certainly gives a different view from the current view we have from Earth. In the centre sits the central cluster of stars and the spiral arms of the galaxy stretch out as a narrow band&nbsp;surrounding it.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image28-qv3sbgkho9.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1142\" /></p><h3>Supernova 1987A</h3><p>The Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) captured and imaged the remnants of this exploded Supernova. The inner regions are highlighted red due to their cold nature. The colour of the outer rings is highly contrasted due to the inner region blasting with the outwards and hitting the gases previously ejected from the Supernova before its detonation.&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image27-lr69anv5qh.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1083\" /></p><h2>The yellow hypergiant star HR 5171</h2><p>This star is a hypergiant - making it 1,300 times bigger than our own Sun. This particular star is one of the largest 10 stars found so far in our exploration of space. The odd shape of this star is actually shown to be down to a companion star sitting close and in direct contact with the main star.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image26-m1abofwtsh.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"999\" /></p><h2>The double-star system GG Tauri-A</h2><p>Data from the&nbsp;Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) has detected this binary system with a large disc around the outside. It is thought that this area could possibly contain Earth-like planets as around half of the Sun-like stars in the Universe are born in binary systems like this one.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image25-s8bxt4zt0d.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1164\" /></p><h2>Mars four billion years ago</h2><p>With previously uncovered evidence that there may well have been <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_on_Mars\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">water on Mars</a>, this image shows what the red planet might have looked like four billion years ago. The surface is likely to have had water pooled on it like our oceans with the majority covering the Northern hemisphere.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image24-hujarsmkfq.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1096\" /></p><h2>The glowing disc of material around the white dwarf SDSS J1228+1040</h2><p>This magnificent image shows a white dwarf star surrounded by a ring of dust and debris. This ring was created when a nearby asteroid was torn apart by the gravity of the white dwarf.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image23-gptlsztjwm.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1068\" /></p><h2>Cosmic spaghetti</h2><p>This is an artists impression of the sheer power of a black hole, the gravitational forces of which are so intense that they would basically turn any person or thing nearby into cosmic spaghetti. Stretching mass and material out of shape as it's pulled into the hole.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image22-8qahutmcbr.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"800\" /></p><h2>A wormhole through time and space</h2><p>This image is an artists impression of a wormhole stretching through space and time. Wormholes are only theoretical and this representation is too, as no one really knows what it would look like inside a tunnel that changes both space and time.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image21-htm4x3bld7.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"800\" /></p><h2>Neutron star over Munich</h2><p>This is a neutron star. These stars are the smallest stars in existence. They are the result of a collapse of a massive star which has exploded and shrunk to a much smaller size. Though smaller (they're not much larger than the city of Munich) neutron stars are extremely dense. It is thought that one teaspoon of matter from these stars&nbsp;would weigh as much as the entire human race.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image20-vblf6dxl5p.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1570\" /></p><h2>The newly-discovered rocky exoplanet, LHS 1140b</h2><p>This planet sits in an orbit around a faint red star in an area which might mean it has water on its surface. It is thought that this planet weighs around six times the weight of Earth and may be habitable.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image19-ohelekl1xg.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1045\" /></p><h2>View from planet in the TRAPPIST-1 planetary System</h2><p>40 light-years from Earth, seven planets orbit an ultracool dwarf star. It is thought that they are an ideal distance from the star to allow there to be water on the surface on several, if not all of them. This image shows what the view might look like from the surface of one of the planets based on what we know the physical parameters of the planets look like.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image18-7kiruax5zy.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"948\" /></p><h2>The most distant quasar</h2><p>A quasar consists of a supermassive black hole surrounded by a mass of gas. As the gas is pulled in towards the black hole, electromagnetic radiation is released that is so powerful it can be observed in a variety of spectrums including radio, infrared, ultraviolet and more. This particular quasar is the most distant we've found and one of the brightest objects in the known Universe.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image17-vjconfpzmt.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1000\" /></p><h2>The hottest and most massive touching double Star</h2><p>Lying 160,000 light-years from Earth, these two giant stars sit in constant contact and share material back and forth. They also make up the hottest and biggest double stars mankind has discovered so far.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image16-6inyvsz0qz.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1130\" /></p><h2>Black hole passing by Earth</h2><p>This artist's impression shows a catastrophic disaster as a black hole passes near Earth and its gravity destroys our planet and extinguishes all life.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image15-eb0bdqykim.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"899\" /></p><h2>The surface of TRAPPIST-1</h2><p>This is another image from&nbsp;TRAPPIST-1 - the zone of planets most likely capable of sustaining life. These planets are located&nbsp;235 trillion miles away from Earth, so it's going to be a while before we see them properly, but they certainly have people excited.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image14-rmr53owkin.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"680\" /></p><h2>The interstellar medium</h2><p>This image is essentially a map of the galaxy as we know it showing \"the interstellar medium\" - the matter and radiation that exists between the systems in the galaxy. This area itself is a&nbsp;valid destination for space probes as it would reveal information and data we don't yet know about the galaxy.&nbsp;</p><p>Find out more about it here -&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/interstellar-crossing-the-cosmic-void\" rel=\"\">https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/interstellar-crossing-the-cosmic-void</a>&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image13-sxuultffcl.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"899\" /></p><h2>Kepler-186f, the first Earth-size planet in the habitable zone</h2><p>This is a depiction of&nbsp;Kepler-186f, another Earth-size planet in orbit of a distant star which might well make it habitable.&nbsp;Kepler-186f is slightly different from Earth though. It only orbits its sun once every 130 days. It is also thought that because&nbsp;Kepler-186f sits at the outer edge of the habitable orbit, the sun would not be as bright as our own - the lunchtime sunshine only being as bright as our sunsets.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image12-4cufuy0op5.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"899\" /></p><h2>Brown dwarf weather</h2><p>Brown dwarfs are giant balls of gas that start out life like stars but don't quite have the power to create the necessary nuclear fusion to become what they were meant to. The result is an unstable surface rife with storms and other activity. This image is a representation of what it might look like.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image11-kpshzut8om.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"900\" /></p><h2>Star surrounded by a protoplanetary disk</h2><p>This illustration shows a star surrounded by a protoplanetary disk. Material from the thick disk flows along the star’s magnetic field lines and is deposited onto the star’s surface. When material hits the star, it lights up brightly.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image10-jyaddp5lvj.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"900\" /></p><h2>Black holes: monsters in space</h2><p>This is a beautiful depiction of one of the most dangerous objects in the Universe - a supermassive black hole. These sorts of black holes are usually found buried at the heart of a galaxy and can be seen surrounded by a mass of gas and dust which is attracted to the hole by its gravitational pull.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image9-halsokchd1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1200\" /></p><h2>Epsilon Eridani system</h2><p>The&nbsp;Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy (SOFIA) is part of&nbsp;NASA’s flying observatory. This observatory has been involved in studying a nearby system with makeup similar to our own. This system is known as the&nbsp;Epsilon Eridani system and is astonishing scientists because of how remarkably similar it is to our system. In this image, a Jupiter-like planet can be seen orbiting the system's sun at the outside-edge of an asteroid belt.&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image8-ds0irfs4vd.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"900\" /></p><h2>Kepler-20e</h2><p>This is&nbsp;Kepler-20e, one of two Earth-sized planets found orbiting a star much like our Sun in another solar system. Both the planets are too close to the star to be able to sustain life, one is so close in fact that a year only lasts six days. The surface temperature is thought to be around 760 degrees Celcius (1,400 degrees Fahrenheit). So it's a bit too toasty!&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image7-ggj8diywo4.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1600\" /></p><h2>Kepler-10 system</h2><p>Located around 560 light-years from Earth sits&nbsp;Kepler-10c, a giant rocky planet that weighs 17 times more than our home planet and is more twice the size. It's a rocky planet, the sort of which astronomers didn't think could exist. Planets this size are usually gaseous bodies, not made of rock.&nbsp;Kepler-10c orbits its sun-like star every 45 days which means it's too hot to sustain life as we know it, but it 's still fascinating.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image6-xtnr7mcpwh.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1088\" /></p><h2>Collection of planets discovered by Kepler</h2><p>So far,&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/kepler/main/index.html\" rel=\"\">NASA's Kepler mission</a> has discovered&nbsp;1,284 new planets, the largest number of planets found so far. This image is a sample of the planetary discoveries made to this point.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><h3><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image5-8y51oxziia.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1600\" height=\"1215\" /></h3><h2>Dead star vaporising a mini planet</h2><p>As stars age and near their death they slowly turn into red giants then eventually shrink down into white dwarf stars. White dwarfs have an extreme gravitational pull and evidence has shown other planets being destroyed by the pull from these collapsing stars. This image is a concept of the devastation caused when this occurs and represents a terrifying view of Earth's future.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image2-jga0ix1egm.jpg\" /></p><h2>ESO discovers Earth-size planet in habitable zone of nearest star</h2><p>Our nearest neighbouring star is known as Proxima Centauri and that star sits in the closest solar system to our own. Orbiting that star is Proxima Centauri - an Earth-sized planet that might be capable of sustaining life and surface water. This image shows the imagined view from the surface, that in the distance includes a view of the double star of Alph Centauri AB as well as Proxima Centurai. Quite a view!&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image2-ancphpq9hs.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1236\" height=\"1600\" /></p><h2>Europa water vapour plume</h2><p>This image shows the surface of the&nbsp;Jovian moon Europa which sits about 500 million miles away from the Sun. Regular plumes of water vapour are seen spouting from the icy surface of the moon. This, combined with other evidence, suggests the presence of a sub-surface ocean below the ice-encrusted surface of the moon.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><img src=\"https://cdn.pocket-lint.com/r/s/660x/assets/images/142413-apps-feature-art-and-science-collide-the-best-in-modern-space-art-image1-npimsu74fx.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1541\" height=\"1600\" /></p><h2>Possible collision at Europa</h2><p>This artist's impression shows what a high-speed collision with Europa might look like. Europa is Jupiter's moon and data from NASA's Galileo mission has shown evidence of a comet or asteroid colliding with the moon at a shallow angle. These collisions leave clay-like minerals and organic compounds, the type of which are found on ancient asteroids and comets.&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p>
